Posts.Content: Hi Matt, Without having read the Grimm study I have the following comments: 1. All treatments have side-effects, surgery gives it all from day one and then it gets better, however how much better varies. Radiation (seeds or EBRT) have fewer side-effects from day one but things tend to come with time (the gift that keeps on giving) So basically it is up to your preferences. So the older you are the more speaks for radiation. 2. Statistics are statistics but you are you. There are studies showing surgery being slightly more advantageous and vice versa. The problem is that to get a statistically significant number of cases you have to look a significant time back, and things have changed in that time so basically the surgery technique used today as well as the radiation technology used today differs from the stuff showed in the statistics. So you will never be able to choose between two very similar roads since they both develop. 3. At the end of the day it is your choice that matters, both seeds, EBRT and surgery is probably similar if done by a skilled professional team. I really almost decided on seeds but changed my mind when the radiation oncologist told me that I would need seeds AND EBRT to treat my tumor. I was just afraid that that much radiation would at the end of the day cause trouble. Also I felt that I would easier be at peace when the thing was physically removed from my body. My wife also supported this. I have no incontinence and ED is ok so I am happy. I also am glad to have a second bullet to fire with radiation if the cancer comes back. But that is me, it is a 50/50 choice and all I can recommend is to find a team you trust and a treatment that you are comfortable with and go for it. There is no given best choice... Good Luck

Posts.Content: Hey Brew, take it easy, G6 and .15 cm tumour is really not bad, and Active surveillance may be a good choice. Posts.Title: Steady as she goes: PSA holding

Posts.Content: Hello Logic, It is not so easy but remember the surgery is not the end of the world, You will be more or less uncomfortable while you have the catheter but then things improve. I tried to spend time with my wife, have really nice dinners and good wine (without overdoing it) long walks trying tp keep busy with fun activities. Not saying that you will not be able to do that later but there will be a period that for some is only uncomfortable, for some painful. The operation as such is really not bad, some pain but not bad, your stomach will be in some disorder and you will have the catheter but not that bad. Good Luck

Posts.Title: After Surgery Update

Posts.Content: Hi Matt, Without having read the Grimm study I have the following comments: 1. All treatments have side-effects, surgery gives it all from day one and then it gets better, however how much better varies. Radiation (seeds or EBRT) have fewer side-effects from day one but things tend to come with time (the gift that keeps on giving) So basically it is up to your preferences. So the older you are the more speaks for radiation. 2. Statistics are statistics but you are you. There are studies showing surgery being slightly more advantageous and vice versa. The problem is that to get a statistically significant number of cases you have to look a significant time back, and things have changed in that time so basically the surgery technique used today as well as the radiation technology used today differs from the stuff showed in the statistics. So you will never be able to choose between two very similar roads since they both develop. 3. At the end of the day it is your choice that matters, both seeds, EBRT and surgery is probably similar if done by a skilled professional team. I really almost decided on seeds but changed my mind when the radiation oncologist told me that I would need seeds AND EBRT to treat my tumor. I was just afraid that that much radiation would at the end of the day cause trouble. Also I felt that I would easier be at peace when the thing was physically removed from my body. My wife also supported this. I have no incontinence and ED is ok so I am happy. I also am glad to have a second bullet to fire with radiation if the cancer comes back. But that is me, it is a 50/50 choice and all I can recommend is to find a team you trust and a treatment that you are comfortable with and go for it. There is no given best choice... Good Luck

Posts.Content: Good to hear that you are doing good. Remember that you are still healing inside, I would not try anything tennis-like for at least a couple of months. Twisting motions are the worst for ripping your insides. Caffeine will increase your leakage, but I donÂ´t think it is dangerous. I think you can try and see what happens. Goes for alcohol also.

Posts.Content: Hello Truckin, and welcome here. You have similar stats to mine, caught it in the nick of time. I had surgery in january 2015 and today I am back to basically normal. Surgery is what very many do and even if it has some drawbacks, at your age you should be fine given that you go to an experienced surgeon. Posts.Title: New to the club

Posts.Content: Hey Brew, take it easy, G6 and .15 cm tumour is really not bad, and Active surveillance may be a good choice. But info on his PSA and age etc. would give more info (remember we are all just sharing experience here, not medical expertise) A small G6 tumor should not have any effect on him in shape of weight loss or stuff like that, however getting a cancer diagnosis really can hit you mentally. There is a theory that none dies of G6 prostate cancer and I would guess that something else is going on causing weight loss and lethargy. But really some info is missing. Read the stickies, Chuck will soon recommend some reading also and try not to worry, this should not be that bad. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Dads biopsy was positive

Posts.Content: Hello Logic, It is not so easy but remember the surgery is not the end of the world, You will be more or less uncomfortable while you have the catheter but then things improve. I tried to spend time with my wife, have really nice dinners and good wine (without overdoing it) long walks trying tp keep busy with fun activities. Not saying that you will not be able to do that later but there will be a period that for some is only uncomfortable, for some painful. The operation as such is really not bad, some pain but not bad, your stomach will be in some disorder and you will have the catheter but not that bad. Good Luck

Posts.Content: Hi Marve, well things are different between countries, probably based on different experiences and histories. Also remember that every person is different and every cancer case is different. Maybe you could go with your father to the doctor and ask how he reasons? It is hard to get information in second hand and your father may not hear everything a doctor says correctly (I did not so my wife joined me to the surgeon) Good thing is that your fathers case is taken seriously and they obviously are trying to give him a cure. Good Luck and take care

Posts.Title: Hormone therapy..how long?

Posts.Content: Well Michael that is of course all good advice but that was not the point. The point is that if the nomograms as you say are "useless" and "to be "thrown into the trash" they should not be published as qualified tools by highly reputable institutions. I realize that there is no way to predict every single case in detail but basically to go from 20% chance of recurrence to 40% in 10 years is a little bit to strong for me to take from the guys who are the experts.

Posts.Title: WooHoo for the < sign!

Posts.Content: Hello Mark, I am so sorry to read that you got it back so soon. But I agree with the others, a lot can be done and many still surprise the doctors. I am sure it is very hard to stay positive but it is important. My mother is one who have surprised many by living with an incurable blood cancer for 15 years now and she is still kicking and I am sure her attitude helped a lot. There is a Swedish band who plays a song that has the title "We are all going to die one day, but all the others we are going to live!" (poor translation) It has helped me in the past. Posts.Title: Radium 233 #3

Posts.Content: This is interesting, I donÂ´t think it is due to any physical changes in the urethtra but maybe, there are clinics in Sweden who clearly claims that you will loose an inch...Since I am no pornstar I stayed away from that clinic. But what is a real issue is (I believe) that the blood flow to the poor penis is reduced after surgery due to nerves being bruised so you get the "after-ice-bath-effect" all the time. Normally your penis is filled with blood during sleep or basically now and then just to keep blood flowing. If this stops you risk long term effects, that is why many of us gets Cialis prescribed, not to have sex, just to get blood flowing. If the penis is without blood for a long time you may risk negative effects. ( this is how I had it explained at least) So it is a good thing to try to get erections even if you donÂ´t have sex, just to "stretch things out a bit " as my surgeon said. Another way of putting it is "Use it or loose it". So my unqualified guess on this is that the surgery as such donÂ´t really shorten it at least if you have a good surgeon, however long time lack of blood flow may. My penis is now able to get hard after 17 months and it is not shorter or thinner but it is a little bit curved.... I donÂ´t know what that means but it is differently shaped and that may be due to the lack of erections. I am guessing here. So what I do is have sex as often as Mrs W can take it and play with myself in-between to stretch it. It is a hobby as good as anything.

Posts.Content: Hello Fred, I agree with everything the others have said but just one small remark, You are not in a BIG hurry to decide, so try to weigh the pros and cons of surgery vs radiation because there is no turning back. I had a similar diagnosis as you, G3+4 and several cores cancerous so treatment was definitely needed. I did surgery in January 2015 and am today almost totally recovered (some ED but basically ok). I did however seriously look into radiation. With my rathjer big tumour I would have needed both external radiation and brachytherapy and it just seemed too elaborated compared to surgery. But take your time to decide and then do not look back. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Is there a not quite zero club?

Posts.Content: Hi Mike, When I made my choice I talked to the surgeon and he advised me to also talk to a radiation team which I did. In Sweden at least they would not recommend doing only Brachy on a tumor of the type I had (described in my signature) but would do Brachy and EBRT. The statistics for a cure is about the same so it is all about your own taste and fears. What turned me to surgery was primarily that I wanted the tumor out and quickly get the results (PSA test can be taken quite soon after surgery and you know if it worked) while radiation results in a slowly declining PSA. As my wife said "You will worry to death before the cancer gets you if you do that..." I was afraid of the side-effects of surgery, my surgeon said that with the size of my tumor he could not guarantee that nerves could be spared...But he managed to do that and now 18 months later I have no problems with incontinence that I care about (it was fine after two months) I can handle ED with pills and mostly important PSA is <0.1. I donÂ´t want to push you in any direction, just give my experience, and I am sure you will be fine with radiation also but donÂ´t rule out the surgery for fear of surgery as such, that is really not bad at all. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Is there a not quite zero club?

Posts.Content: Hi WiW, I have no experience of the drugs you ask about however I have some experience of friends and close ones with terminal cancer. It is probably very very hard to accept that you are dying but the fact that there is no cure does not mean that you cannot live your life in an acceptable way. My mother has had terminal cancer for 14 years, she will die from it at some point but the years she has had have at times been very good. I also had a colleague who was in palliative care for at least two years and even if he suffered he still had good days and stayed with us for a long time. I know this is a very poor comfort but what these two have learned me is that every day has a value and being terminal may not mean that every day and every hour is bad. But this is probably very easy to say and very different when you are in that situation yourself. Take care

Posts.Title: DaVinci surgery results in shorter penis??

Posts.Content: Hi Mike, When I made my choice I talked to the surgeon and he advised me to also talk to a radiation team which I did. In Sweden at least they would not recommend doing only Brachy on a tumor of the type I had (described in my signature) but would do Brachy and EBRT. The statistics for a cure is about the same so it is all about your own taste and fears. What turned me to surgery was primarily that I wanted the tumor out and quickly get the results (PSA test can be taken quite soon after surgery and you know if it worked) while radiation results in a slowly declining PSA. As my wife said "You will worry to death before the cancer gets you if you do that..." I was afraid of the side-effects of surgery, my surgeon said that with the size of my tumor he could not guarantee that nerves could be spared...But he managed to do that and now 18 months later I have no problems with incontinence that I care about (it was fine after two months) I can handle ED with pills and mostly important PSA is <0.1. I donÂ´t want to push you in any direction, just give my experience, and I am sure you will be fine with radiation also but donÂ´t rule out the surgery for fear of surgery as such, that is really not bad at all. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Newbie: From Lurker to Club Member

Posts.Content: This is interesting, I donÂ´t think it is due to any physical changes in the urethtra but maybe, there are clinics in Sweden who clearly claims that you will loose an inch...Since I am no pornstar I stayed away from that clinic. But what is a real issue is (I believe) that the blood flow to the poor penis is reduced after surgery due to nerves being bruised so you get the "after-ice-bath-effect" all the time. Normally your penis is filled with blood during sleep or basically now and then just to keep blood flowing. If this stops you risk long term effects, that is why many of us gets Cialis prescribed, not to have sex, just to get blood flowing. If the penis is without blood for a long time you may risk negative effects. ( this is how I had it explained at least) So it is a good thing to try to get erections even if you donÂ´t have sex, just to "stretch things out a bit " as my surgeon said. Another way of putting it is "Use it or loose it". So my unqualified guess on this is that the surgery as such donÂ´t really shorten it at least if you have a good surgeon, however long time lack of blood flow may. My penis is now able to get hard after 17 months and it is not shorter or thinner but it is a little bit curved.... I donÂ´t know what that means but it is differently shaped and that may be due to the lack of erections. I am guessing here. So what I do is have sex as often as Mrs W can take it and play with myself in-between to stretch it. It is a hobby as good as anything.

Posts.Content: Hi Jeff, I assume you are in USA? If not it may be tricky to get the track record of the surgeons without actually asking them directly (which I had to do in Sweden). You have already been given good advice above but I would like to add that with your diagnosis you are NOT in a hurry to take decisions, take your time until you feel reasonably ok with your decision. I was diagnosed in October 14 and was operated last week.

Posts.Title: 1 step forward, 2 steps back - incontinence

Posts.Content: Hi Daughter, Well 10 biopsies positive is not good as you say but the important thing is that he was clean in the other scan and it may not have escaped the prostate. Hormones and radiation as recommended is quite common and as I get it 8 weeks is standard. The other option is surgery, both have the same success rates. It is hard to give more advice without a detailed biopsy report, what was his PSA? what was the G-score of the biopsies? to what extend (%) were the samples cancerous? At least is Sweden they tend to recommend radiation for the more advanced cases with the motivation that the odds are you will need it anyway and then the surgery is an unnecessary action. But this is not in any way a clear cut and I strongly recommend you to get a second opinion on surgery also. Try to relax, if this is contained in the prostate your father has a good chance to fix it. If you are to have cancer, prostate cancer is the one to have since there are options to fix it and slow it down. Having said that you really need to get the biopsy report to understand what you are dealing with and how much in a hurry you are. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Concerned. All 10 biopsies came back positive

Posts.Content: Well, you can expect days like this for some time. Too much Kegels can do it and so can too few. In my case it was mostly too much Kegels, too few was basically when I forgot about them totally for a couple of days. Also in the beginning the more you move around the more it leaks which is tricky since you need to move around also. But you are only two weeks out, I needed 6 weeks to be back to one small squirt/day. And also the recovery is not linear and bad days will come but more and more seldom. Try to just forget the bad days, they mean nothing for your recovery. I still keep a pad and a pair of briefs in my briefcase......

Posts.Title: New Member/Maiden Voyage

Posts.Content: Hello LetÂ´s, I am 52 and now 4 weeks behind surgery. This place is the place to be, It has helped me a lot. You will get good answers and also read the stickies at the top. Basically I would say since he is only 50 some treatment is needed. G6 and early stage to me sounds "fixable" but get the correct G-number and staging from the doctors. If he is G6 and early stage you have time to decide and educate yourself. DonÂ´t panic. Also for us it was a big help to be two at all meetings since you tend to be slightly shocked at some times. Panic attacks may pop up. But please take my advice for what it is, non-expert only based on my experience. Good luck and take care

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed husband - ?'s to ask Doc at our first appt?

Posts.Content: The bladder is repositioned during surgery and then it is not really filled during the time with the catheter so it takes some time for it to stretch and adjust to the new positioning. I think that is why it takes some time to get it to fill up properly. But it eventually does and then all the strange feelings decrease. One thing that probably never go away is that when it is full and you need to pee, you need to do it NOW! So if you see a guy in a shopping center scouting and memorizing the restrooms it is probably one uf us.

Posts.Content: Hello FLA, and welcome. Sorry to hear that you have cancer but it is a G6 which is highly treatable and curable. And also not aggressive so you have time to get educated and make an informed decision on what you should do. Read the books recommended and read the stickies threads at the top. Most guys here have done surgery but several have done radiation also. You will get answers to all your questions here. Good Luck

Posts.Content: Hello LetÂ´s, I am 52 and now 4 weeks behind surgery. This place is the place to be, It has helped me a lot. You will get good answers and also read the stickies at the top. Basically I would say since he is only 50 some treatment is needed. G6 and early stage to me sounds "fixable" but get the correct G-number and staging from the doctors. If he is G6 and early stage you have time to decide and educate yourself. DonÂ´t panic. Also for us it was a big help to be two at all meetings since you tend to be slightly shocked at some times. Panic attacks may pop up. But please take my advice for what it is, non-expert only based on my experience. Good luck and take care

Posts.Content: Hello FLA, and welcome. Sorry to hear that you have cancer but it is a G6 which is highly treatable and curable. And also not aggressive so you have time to get educated and make an informed decision on what you should do. Read the books recommended and read the stickies threads at the top. Most guys here have done surgery but several have done radiation also. You will get answers to all your questions here. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with prostate cancer

Posts.Content: The bladder is repositioned during surgery and then it is not really filled during the time with the catheter so it takes some time for it to stretch and adjust to the new positioning. I think that is why it takes some time to get it to fill up properly. But it eventually does and then all the strange feelings decrease. One thing that probably never go away is that when it is full and you need to pee, you need to do it NOW! So if you see a guy in a shopping center scouting and memorizing the restrooms it is probably one uf us.

Posts.Content: I think it is normal, your bowels have been moved around and stuff have been removed from in there. It feels weird in the stomach some time after the surgery. You should not push to hard when having a BM in the beginning so try to eat softening food, prunes, fluids. You donÂ´t want to be constipated. But it will feel strange for a couple of months I would say.

Posts.Title: Crossed over into the "normal" zone...

Posts.Content: Hi Sandra, and welcome. We have many daughters on the forum right now, read their threads and you will get more help. I think you should try to take it easy just now. Even if a PSA of 25 for sure indicates cancer, it is not disaster high and there is still good chance that this can be cured, by surgery and/or radiation. I also think that chemo is a long time away yet. But the data from the biopsy would give more info. Just for now I think it is important that you both get educated before he takes some drastic (unwise) decisions. Really do read the book recommended by Chuck and you will realize that this may not be the disaster you think yet. And to be perfectly clear, prostate cancer can be cured if caught in time and it can be stopped for many years with hormone treatments if it has spread, but it can NOT be fixed with anything else. And I donÂ´t want to be blunt here but if your father goes into alternative treatments too soon he just may miss the window of opportunity to fix this and believe me, that he does not want to happen. Please read the book and try to get educated to make a better decision than going "alternative" Good Luckl

Posts.Title: Post-op questions

Posts.Content: Hi Kate, I think that the surgeon tried to avoid positive margins and decided to cut wider. You will know when you get the pathology results. The fact that the tumor was in both lobes is really not that important now since it is gone. I know it is hard but you cannot draw any conclusions until you get the pathology results. I guess that others will comment also but so far I have heard nothing but good about Dr Tewari who seems to know what he is doing so donÂ´t be discouraged. The catheter is a nuisance but will soon be gone. Also you should be aware that after surgery you can get very emotional and have mood swings, this will go away in a short time and the mood will be better. Good Luck and stay positive, worst is probably done now.

Posts.Title: Trimix Gel????

Posts.Content: Hello SeaCock, Trimix is not available in Sweden but I did test Alprostadil as a gel. You were supposed to drop it down your Urethtra and then some would end up just around there and you should massage that in. For me the Muse worked better, but remember that when I tried the gel I had basically no led whatsoever in my pencil so I guess I needed something stronger. HavenÂ´t tried it since because it is not covered by my insurance but Muse is. Good Luck and maybe you should try to combine it with Viagra to get a real boost

Posts.Title: ED depression,

Posts.Content: Hi Sandra, and welcome. We have many daughters on the forum right now, read their threads and you will get more help. I think you should try to take it easy just now. Even if a PSA of 25 for sure indicates cancer, it is not disaster high and there is still good chance that this can be cured, by surgery and/or radiation. I also think that chemo is a long time away yet. But the data from the biopsy would give more info. Just for now I think it is important that you both get educated before he takes some drastic (unwise) decisions. Really do read the book recommended by Chuck and you will realize that this may not be the disaster you think yet. And to be perfectly clear, prostate cancer can be cured if caught in time and it can be stopped for many years with hormone treatments if it has spread, but it can NOT be fixed with anything else. And I donÂ´t want to be blunt here but if your father goes into alternative treatments too soon he just may miss the window of opportunity to fix this and believe me, that he does not want to happen. Please read the book and try to get educated to make a better decision than going "alternative" Good Luckl

Posts.Content: Hello Jaybee, as the guys already say, he is doing fine, the pathology report is good. And since it looks like the cancer was contained surgery was a very good choice. If it will come back he has the opportunity to radiate it to get rid of the remains. DonÂ´t worry about him looking pale, it probably has nothing to do with cancer but with the fact that he has had mayor surgery and it hurts. It is also easy to get a little emotional after the surgery and it takes some time to be happy again. Also the ED will cause some downs but that will become better with time and help. He probably just needs your support and care, remember that he may also be cured from the cancer! it looks like that from the report. Good Luck

Posts.Title: The Countdown Begins

Posts.Content: Hi Scurrent, Well I can only offer sympathy, I have no idea what went wrong but it sounds as something did. With nerve-sparing surgery it can take some time but after a year I would guess that some small sign of life should come back. And same on leakage. But I am only a guy no expert, having a surgeon that you trust is very important and if you together can for a plan of action that is really valuable. But also we are all different and for some guys it takes longer to heal. I spoke to a guy who had surgery about five years ago and he still think that things are improving for every day. I can really feel your pain but donÂ´t give up, it will improve, and you are cancer free! Take care

Posts.Title: Update on my cancer

Posts.Content: Welcome Oregon, Me as many others donÂ´t believe in any food supplements curing cancer. They may for sure reduce the risk of ever getting cancer but when it has developed it is another game. For me it is like hitting the brakes after you have already crashed. I do beieve in eating healthy and exercise but mainly to be able to cope with the treatments. Your father have a "nice" type of cancer and he may well wait for some time to get treatment (if he ever needs it) but I strongly recommend to keep track of how it develops and use the time to get informed on treatment options and make a plan. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Thought I was doing great!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate Prowler, Something else to be aware of: on December 11, 2017, Pfizer's US patent on Viagra will no longer be exclusive, as the generic version from the Israeli firm Teva will then be available at about one fourth of the current cost. Teva's sildenafil has been available in Canada for about three years, after their Supreme Court invalidated Pfizer's patent. Buy your ED meds from there until 12/2017. This already happened in Europe, so I use only generic Sildenafil now. It works better than Cialis on me. One pill is about 3 bucks.

Posts.Title: Need help with my two options, VMAT or Proton

Posts.Content: Hi, I am about to have the prostate removed Jan 7, in three days, with daVinci surgery. I have no second thoughts, my surgeon has long experience and I trust him. My wife is very supportive and so are all my friends. I do worry a little about incontinence and ED but at my age and based on internet witnesses I will probably be just fine and good chances to get cancer free. So Hooray! But here comes my question: I still feel really depressed, not able to enjoy the good things in life, not even the sex. I feel like crying very often and drink more wine than I should. Hopefully this will go away next week when all is done but do you guys have similar experiences? I do not want to complain and I know I am lucky to get this fixed so my brain understands that I am fine, but my heart just seems not to get it...

Posts.Title: Depressions, do you guys get them?

Posts.Content: Hello Kate, not much to add but I am another one that did surgery. I was also offered Brachy as a choice but decided for surgery mainly because you get an answer almost immediately if the treatment was succesful. With any radiation it takes time to know if it worked. My wife said I would worry to death if I did that and she was probably right on that. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Depressions, do you guys get them?

Posts.Content: Hi Stuntmole, you are probably right that this is not real depression and I basically try to do what you do, just go on doing what needs to be done. It is probably the constant nagging inside your head that finally wears you down. I also think about cancer ALL the time. I probably could never go for AS, it is just not for me. Thanks for your reply, sometimes I guess it is just good to hear that there are others with the same issues. I will now watch "Guardians of the Galaxy" and not think of cancer for a while. Good luck to you also!

Posts.Title: Depressions, do you guys get them?

Posts.Content: Hi Chiguy, not much more to add but to confirm Michaels concern, you should get a second opinion with those figures. Having said that you have time to get educated and time to make a decision. AS is fine done correctly and it certainly postpones the side-effect risks of all treatments. However at some point you might want to take treatment and you should then be educated to be able to weigh your risks and your willingness to gamble versus the side-effect risks. Plenty of information here and in the stickies above Good Luck

Posts.Title: 3 month psa

Posts.Content: and the verdict from the jury is......drumroll.........<0.05. I am quite relieved. And apart from that the incontinence is not an issue anymore, very rare ghostsquirts, that is almost all. And ED is ok, not as before but ok. I just had a chat with a colleague who had surgery 3 years ago and he said that ED for him is still improving, which felt good to hear. So all you newly diagnosed, things get better and there is life after treatment. I think I will have a drink tonight and sit in the sun with a stupid grin on my face.

Posts.Title: Membership renewal

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 Hi Wilde: Very glad to hear that news. I note your latest PSA reading (<0.05) in your history differs from your previous results (<0.1) and now appears that you may be utilizing a more sensitive assay machine. Is that the case? Jim Yep, they have changed the "standard" of PSA-testing. Sweden differs a little from USA since the care is highly regulated which means that every lab here uses the same technology and the same level of detail. So the answer I got also came with a comment explaining that the new national standard is 0.05 as lowest level replacing 0.1. Still the <-sign is the most important.

Posts.Title: Merry Christmas Everyone!

Posts.Content: ItÂ´s an interesting question, the thing is that it is hard to define cured. As DjinTonic says it can come back after a very long time, does that mean that you are never cured? well maybe but if you define cured as having the same odds as any guy to get cancer it gets a little easier to grasp. Since it is all about statistics I prefer to see it as just that, my odds of getting cancer is in the same range as any guy. The difference is that we who once have had it knows that it can come back and so we think about it, most other guys never think about their odds of getting cancer. When I got PC me and my wife agreed that we should get the date when I was "cured" tattooed in a heart on both of us, well that never happened, a tattoo with "93% cured 20150109" just seems weird... But as long as your PSA is 0 you are as "cured" as it is possible to be which probably is good enough.

Posts.Content: Hello Sawdustmaker, I had a similar diagnosis as you have and went for surgery. I would recommend to bring someone with you to the visit to the surgeon, even if you seems to be really well prepared it is a stressful meeting and hit is easy to forget to ask the questions you planned and even harder to remember the answers. Or take notes. DonÂ´t worry about the surgery, it is not that bad at all for most guys. And you will be sorted out in the order Michael mentions which is important to remember. For me two years after surgery it is just a bump in the road and I wish you all luck.

Posts.Content: Hello Kevin, Take it easy is the best advice. It is a major surgery and it would be strange if it didnÂ´t affect you. (Think of it as having been stabbed 5 times in the stomach..). DonÂ´t lift and twist, it is bad and hurts. Try to walk as much as you can but donÂ´t overdo it. It is good that you take the 6 weeks, after 4 you will be fine. Running to the bathroom is normal (at least I did it too), the bladder is unused to be stretched after the catheter but that will improve. If you are concerned about the incontinence try to weigh your pads and calculate your daily leak. It will show the improvement even if you donÂ´t feel it. I had similar data as you (3+4 and a large tumor) and also felt the "having dodged a bullet" for a long time. In the first week after surgery this made me quite emotional, I thought I was going mad but it went away rather soon. Take your weeks off and take care, soon this will be behind you Good Luck

Posts.Title: BRACHY REPORT...6 Months Out

Posts.Content: Hello Dave, I have followed your threads and your PC journey is a rough one, you have all my sympaties. I have no real advice but I would like to share this with you: My mother has had terminal cancer now for almost 14 years. Many with her type of cancer does not live for more than a few years, the response to treatment is very different and individual. She is now 76 and noone really knows how long she has. Also: Just Before Christmas I was attending a funeral for a colleague who had terminal cancer for many years. He was in palliative care for two years. He had a relatively good life until the last three days (which honestly were bad). What I am trying to say here is that we never know how much time we have and now and then time is longer than we think. I truly hope that your time will be long enough to achieve what you need and want to. Take care and please keep posting

Posts.Title: Update on Secondary Treatment

Posts.Content: Hi Delta, and welcome here. For me it took around a year to get back from ED. I still use Viagra but not sure if I really need them anymore. For the first 6 months after surgery basically nothing worked well enough. I did use Muse (or Bondil as it is called here) and it worked but it hurts a lot. My surgeon urged me to use them even without having sex "to stretch things out a bit" and I think that is a good thing. You may not want to hear this but I think you should be prepared for a poor year, if it goes quicker that is good but it sounds among the guys here that a year is pretty much average time. But do keep trying and maybe use Muse, it might work, specially with a younger wife

Posts.Title: Still in the Zero club!

Posts.Content: Hi Delta, and welcome here. For me it took around a year to get back from ED. I still use Viagra but not sure if I really need them anymore. For the first 6 months after surgery basically nothing worked well enough. I did use Muse (or Bondil as it is called here) and it worked but it hurts a lot. My surgeon urged me to use them even without having sex "to stretch things out a bit" and I think that is a good thing. You may not want to hear this but I think you should be prepared for a poor year, if it goes quicker that is good but it sounds among the guys here that a year is pretty much average time. But do keep trying and maybe use Muse, it might work, specially with a younger wife

Posts.Title: One year out and it was like it never happened

Posts.Content: Hello Mark, and welcome here. It is good that you found this place, it is a goldmine of information. And also full of guys with more or less bad cancers but still alive and kicking which have helped at least me a lot. It is amazing how quick your PSA went down after treatment and it certainly seems to be doing good. Also being able to tackle this with humor and an equally humorous wife is a great help. When I mentioned that I would probably have ED to my wife she said "finally a vacation" and we could laugh at it. I wish you all luck with your treatment and please keep posting.

Posts.Content: I went for daVinci myself, my surgeon is experienced in laparoscopic as well as daVinci and he is happier with daVinci and so am I. I also checked the other surgeons at my hospital and there they all have now "converted" to daVinci and only use open surgery on really large prostates. Since you are not in the same country as i this may be of little help but what I am getting at is the same as many others, get an experienced surgeon and if you trust him/her the method is probably better to let them choose. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Leaning toward surgery; don't know what kind I'd select

Posts.Content: Hello Mark, and welcome here. It is good that you found this place, it is a goldmine of information. And also full of guys with more or less bad cancers but still alive and kicking which have helped at least me a lot. It is amazing how quick your PSA went down after treatment and it certainly seems to be doing good. Also being able to tackle this with humor and an equally humorous wife is a great help. When I mentioned that I would probably have ED to my wife she said "finally a vacation" and we could laugh at it. I wish you all luck with your treatment and please keep posting.

Posts.Title: Getting tough to deal with

Posts.Content: Hi Kamie, I really have not very much to add to the guys responses but to add my view. Living healthy is a good thing, donÂ´t misunderstand us, it can increase the ability of your immune system and in some cases reducing the risks of getting cancer. It is also very good to be fit to be able to cope with any health issues. But when the cancer is there it will not go away. A smoker who gets lung cancer will not be cured by stop smoking either. But a G6 cancer is NOT a death sentence. There are lots of options and many G6 guys do Active Surveillance for many years, and some reach the end of their lives for other reasons never needing treatment for the cancer. But there is a very dangerous issue with prostate cancer and that is that it often donÂ´t give any symptoms until it is too late and if the cancer spreads there is no cure. There are very good treatments to keep it controlled for many years though. With a G6 you have time to get educated on the issue. Read the book recommended and read the stories here. By all means live healthy and exercise. DonÂ´t smoke and cut down on read meat. When it comes to surgery and/or radiation there are many stories in here describng what to expect in side-effects and recovery time and very many are happy to get the cancer out. What made your husbands brother regret his surgery? You can fix this, it is not that bad. But please donÂ´t believe it will go away by food supplements or similar, it wonÂ´t. Good Luck and take care

Posts.Title: One year anniversary....

Posts.Content: Well here is my theory: there are things that may slow your cancer down, like cutting red meat and stop smoking and drinking. Also exercising is good. I think this strengthen the immune system. But I think it is mostly important to prevent you from getting cancer at all. I think it is in no way a cure when the cancer has got you. However to generally be of good health helps the treatments you get. Being fat and unfit increases risks at surgery for example. I try to eat healthy and to exercise but if I ever get another cancer I would not try diets to fix the cancer. But I am no expert in this.

Posts.Title: That was then and this is now.

Posts.Content: Hi Bernard, I have the same issues with some of my friends, same arguments. What I think is important is that there are several forums like this as well as different discussion groups and so on where real people who have had cancer can witness on treatments, cures and also unfortunately failing treatments. These people are real people living with cancer. I assure you that you will not find these types of groups of people being treated by whatever "alternative" options. You will however find a lot of "I heard about a guy from a friend who cured himself with snake oil! You should try it!" Also if the "Gig Pharma Conspiracy" was true probably no-one working there and no-one working with cancer would ever die or take any treatment, but they do, as the rest of us.... It is your life, you only have one shot, listen to the guys who have been in your situation and by all means get a doctor you trust. That is my advice Good Luck

Posts.Content: I had gas issues for about a month, not specially in the morning but just big amounts of gas. That has gone away now but for sure the plumbing is different and lots of things feels different in the lower abdomen. That will probably always be so. And not doing number 2 and 1 at the same time seems almost impossible but is not a big problem. The gas should go away, otherwise there are medications for that. And pain should also go away but it will still feel different.

He said "ten" I was horrified and asked "Ten what, years? months? weeks ?" He said "nine....."

You might want a second opinion on the biopsy, to be really certain what you are dealing with. Posts.Title: Just diagnosed, many questions

Posts.Content: Hello Runlikewind, As the others say fPSA is an indicator of cancer if combined with a high PSA. It is expressed in % and I am not sure how to interpret your number but a low fPSA <15% indicates cancer. But it is not really that important, with two PSA-tests of 8-10 with antibiotics between you should take the DRE and if it was me the biopsy also. PSA can go up and down and the only way to be sure is the biopsy. And really it is not as bad as it sounds. Just abandon all dignity and you will be fine.

Posts.Title: Question about fPSA number??

Posts.Content: I think that statistically the forums are a little biased since (as you say) many men who are cured just move on but the ones who have a recurrence stay and continue sharing their stories. We both have a G3+4 and as I understand it the chances of being cured with surgery only are worse compared to G3+3 however the odds of getting cured with surgery and follow-up radiation is really high. So you probably do not need to worry at all. So that is very good. But the other issue than statistics is to live with the worry of recurrence, and in my case that the final pathology should be upgraded to something higher than 3+4 which keeps me awake at nights since G8 or higher is a different animal to live with. I have one week to the first PSA and final pathology and it is really getting to me. Last week I told a friend of the odds and all that and the weird thing was that he almost cried, not I, but it did nothing to help me stop worrying. Sorry about the rant but I think that the odds of being cured are unfortunately not reflected in the worry we actually have to live with.

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed, many questions

Posts.Content: Hi Badman, yeah orgasming is different, not sure if it is a bad thing though, it is just different. I was lucky since I had no problems with urine leakage during sex but it is different. Absolutely no issues whatsoever with not lasting long enough, that is just not an issue anymore. Also when it finally gets hard enough (which takes some time and requires Viagra) it stays hard for a long time. So bottom line is it is different now, not necessarily worse. It is what it is....

Posts.Title: PSA Results

Posts.Content: Hello Runlikewind, As the others say fPSA is an indicator of cancer if combined with a high PSA. It is expressed in % and I am not sure how to interpret your number but a low fPSA <15% indicates cancer. But it is not really that important, with two PSA-tests of 8-10 with antibiotics between you should take the DRE and if it was me the biopsy also. PSA can go up and down and the only way to be sure is the biopsy. And really it is not as bad as it sounds. Just abandon all dignity and you will be fine.

Posts.Title: Question about fPSA number??

Posts.Content: HI Delta, Our data is quite similar, I am also a G3+4 and also had some small positive margins, I think 4 mm. Statistically positive margins will increase your risk of a recurrence but with a veeeery small number. It is also common that the prostate gets squeezed while removing it which creates a "false" positive margin (the tumor was squeezed towards the surface). I think all of us have PSA angst and for me it actually gets worse for every time even though statistically every zero means reduced risk of reoccurrence. Last time I almost cried when I got the results... You have a quite low-risk situation but it is not a 100% no risk situation but the more time passes the better it is. I strongly recommend a glass of wine or similar after every 0 PSA to celebrate. If I ever get a not 0 PSA I will probably have two glasses... Try to relax, You have done all you can and will probably be just fine

Posts.Title: 6 months Post-Op and nervous about PSA

Posts.Content: Hello Lilguy, and welcome here, the place where noone really wants to be. But there are lots of well informed guys here. I am no expert but since you have been keeping track of your PSA and it is not very high and with a biopsy where 1 of 14 showed 10% G3+3 you might not need to do anything right now but track it. Also this diagnosis has very high chances of being cured no matter what treatment you choose, and you have time to get informed and choose whatever suits you best. You might want a second opinion on the biopsy, to be really certain what you are dealing with. DonÂ´t panic, talk to your urologist and maybe also book an appointment with an oncologist for a second opinion. I am sure the more experienced guys will also give further advice. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Good news on ED

Posts.Content: HI Delta, Our data is quite similar, I am also a G3+4 and also had some small positive margins, I think 4 mm. Statistically positive margins will increase your risk of a recurrence but with a veeeery small number. It is also common that the prostate gets squeezed while removing it which creates a "false" positive margin (the tumor was squeezed towards the surface). I think all of us have PSA angst and for me it actually gets worse for every time even though statistically every zero means reduced risk of reoccurrence. Last time I almost cried when I got the results... You have a quite low-risk situation but it is not a 100% no risk situation but the more time passes the better it is. I strongly recommend a glass of wine or similar after every 0 PSA to celebrate. If I ever get a not 0 PSA I will probably have two glasses... Try to relax, You have done all you can and will probably be just fine

Posts.Title: WHO report on red meat

Posts.Content: Hi Oshguy, Ah the agony of Pathology report interpretation, it is tough. In all I think newporter is correct, it is not that bad and your surgeon did a good job. I spent about 2 months worrying about positive margins which I had but unfortunately there is nothing we can do but keep track of the PSA. And if it goes up, radiate it. So I have stopped worrying about it, at least all the time. The cancer might come back, lightning mighy strike or a car might hit me. Keep PSA tracked and try not to worry. Take care

Posts.Title: YIPPIE and YAHOO!!

Posts.Content: Hello Hammer, and welcome here. Not much to add from the others but to say that we have similar cancers you and I. I was diagnosed when I was 52, G3+4 but I had more cores than you. Well I did the surgery in january 2015 and have no regrets at all. For sure it hurt but really what hurt most was my dignity. I was incontinent for a couple of weeks, not that bad at all and today I only have the rare small squirt when I squeeze some part of my wife (it is really weird). ED took about a year to get to ok. It freaked me out in the beginning but now I am basically back to normal. I use Viagra but I think that is more psychological today. What I am trying to say is that soon this will be only a memory for you, you have caught this in good time and with your low relatively low PSA I would be surprised if it is not contained in the prostate. Try to relax and have all the sex you can before surgery. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Husbands PSA undetectable!

Posts.Content: Hello Wayne, With 3+4 you should do something no matter how your PSA fluctuates, which it very often does. But remember what is the chicken and egg here, you have 3+4, this increases your PSA. This does not mean that if your PSA decreases your 3+4 is cured. I am sorry to say but that is not how this works. We all make our bets and have our beliefs but at age 61 and with a 3+4 I would not risk the quality of life for the upcoming many years by delaying treatment. Radiation (sometimes combined with hormone treatment) or surgery is at the end of the day, a matter of taste. I wish you good luck

AgeInfo.Phrase: our beliefs but at age 61 and with a 3 4

Posts.Title: Dropped Trial

Posts.Content: Hello Valar, I am so sorry to hear about your husbands situation, and as you say it seems that it is serious. But bone scans and MRI are clear so I would hit it and hit it hard, and soon. Pratoman is giving you good advice on seeing an oncologist. As I had it explained the bigger the tumor the more speaks for radiation as a possible first treatment. But I am not a doctor. Your view of first hitting the cancer and then think about the side-effects is really healthy. That priority is easy to forget but you have it right. Finding a doctor you trust and who is experienced in his/hers field is really important. Good Luck and donÂ´t panic, several people here that can offer support

Posts.Title: Twelve Weeks Post RALP

Posts.Content: Hello jdsky, I remember those last days before surgery, if it is one thing we learn in this game it is to wait. But it will soon be over and after the surgery time seems to move rather quick. In 144 hours you will probably feel quite ok albeit with a hose up your penis. I am sure you are well prepared but one small tip I will give you, the strong painkillers (morphine, oxycontin) will stop your stomach from working and you will clog up. This hurts after a prostatectomy, so try to eat as little as you can manage of painkillers and eat fibrous stuff to get your bowels moving again. Drink a lot, the catheter has the advantage that you donÂ´t have to get up to pee. Hug your wife and Good Luck.

Posts.Title: Some advice

Posts.Content: Hello Dogdollar, I understand if you are disappointed with the upgrade to G9 but remember that now it is out and gone. This is actually one of the advantages of surgery, you get an exact final answer of what is going on and can act on it, even if that answer is not what you wanted. Thanks for posting your doctors notes, it is always interesting to read their clinical and a little dry descriptions. I still remember my surgeons writing that "the patient is inside-fat" which made me laugh. I have also been recommended a pump but as you say I just canÂ´t bring me to do that. Enjoy your sausage and wine, it is a great combo.

Posts.Title: My Post-Op Pathology

Posts.Content: I donÂ´t think the enema is that important, it is for sure inconvenient if you are "full" after the biopsy so do take it. I was not prepared at all for the biopsy, my normal doctor who discovered the high PSA sent me to a specialist and at the first meeting with him he just told me "And now we will take a biopsy" so I swallowed an antibiotic and then it was pants down..... No enema and no other preparation and I was fine, dignity was severely abused but that was it. Good Luck

Posts.Content: Hello jdsky, I remember those last days before surgery, if it is one thing we learn in this game it is to wait. But it will soon be over and after the surgery time seems to move rather quick. In 144 hours you will probably feel quite ok albeit with a hose up your penis. I am sure you are well prepared but one small tip I will give you, the strong painkillers (morphine, oxycontin) will stop your stomach from working and you will clog up. This hurts after a prostatectomy, so try to eat as little as you can manage of painkillers and eat fibrous stuff to get your bowels moving again. Drink a lot, the catheter has the advantage that you donÂ´t have to get up to pee. Hug your wife and Good Luck.

Posts.Title: Bondil for ED?

Posts.Content: I donÂ´t think the enema is that important, it is for sure inconvenient if you are "full" after the biopsy so do take it. I was not prepared at all for the biopsy, my normal doctor who discovered the high PSA sent me to a specialist and at the first meeting with him he just told me "And now we will take a biopsy" so I swallowed an antibiotic and then it was pants down..... No enema and no other preparation and I was fine, dignity was severely abused but that was it. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Firstpost

Posts.Content: Good News Stuntmole! I am also on Muse, but here it is called Bondil. It works, but it also hurts. It takes a couple of times to get used to it and the first times it did not work so well for me. My doctor told me to use them twice a week even if I should not have sex "to stretch things out a bit". I have not used it more than once a week but last time (tenth try) I think I may have been able to use it for more fun activities. Showed it to wife who said "Hm, that might actually work!" I take them before I shower at night. It is interesting to see little Wilde grow but then the pain comes and to be frank to you, the first time it felt like I had hit him with a hammer...But it gets better for every time so donÂ´t give up on Muse, keep trying. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Little humor to brighten your day

Posts.Content: Hi Alex, I was 52 when I got PC and my youngest daughter was 21, oldest 23, and I remember how hard it was for them to handle the fact that daddy was ill. Fathers always want to protect their daughters and your father probably is too. You may want to talk to his doctor instead to get correct information, your father probably has a hard time telling you everything. It is hard to comment on survival rates with this little information but I know one thing and that is that statistics is one thing but the variations in survival time is large, There are many guys here who are on hormone treatment right now and they know more than me. I am sorry to say but your father seems to be very ill with a PSA of 83, and aggressive treatment will be needed, but donÂ´t give up, there is always hope and you may have many years of good time ahead of you. Take care and I wish you both good luck

Posts.Content: Hi 2b-lucky, and welcome here. You ask a tricky question, as I understand a G6 normally donÂ´t spread outside the prostate. But on the other hand a biopsy can never detect everything going on inside and if it has missed something the closeness to the edge might increase the risk. But I am not a professional, just a guy who had PC. Your data would be useful in advising, as age, PSA history and so on.. I am sure the other guys also will ask where you are been treated, I cannot advice on that since I am in Sweden. Good Luck and take care

Posts.Title: I can now sleep

Posts.Content: Hello Alpine, sorry about your diagnosis but you are in a good place here to get info. I have no experience of such a large tumour that you seems to have however I strongly agree with lancepeace that you should very soon treat it. You are probably still "lucky" in that it seems to be contained in the prostate but that will not last forever and I would grab the opportunity to go for a cure soon. When it comes to surgery vs radiation it is tricky, it is true that many of us have reasoned that if I do surgery first I have the opportunity to do radiation later. That has been with smaller tumours though. The advice I got from both the urologist and onchologist was that generally the bigger the tumour the more speaks for radiation/hormone treatment. I am not sure exactly why. Good luck and I am sure others will also answer you

Posts.Title: Happy Thanksgiving 2016!

Posts.Content: Hello Jlynn, It is not that bad at all. If your husband have had surgery before he will know what to expect. Of course the stomach area will be sore, after all there are 5 holes in it, and also his bottom will hurt when he sits. (that might also come a little later). The most common complain afterwards seems to be gas-pains in the shoulders (sounds strange but the nerves obviously work like that) and gas pains from the stomach. Walking and eating correct food helps with this. Painkillers also slows down the digestive system so trying to use as little as possible of them is good. He will not feel well for a week but it will be bearable, that is my personal view. The catheter is not much to worry about, it is actually a help since he will not need to get up at nights to pee. Many people here thinks it is the worst part, I thought it was not so bad. And it does not hurt to take it out. (Well apart from a very hurt dignity....) Later on after catheter removal the continence is the big issue. See to it that the Kegels are done and also not overdone, stick to the schedule your surgeon gives you. Some get continent quickly, some takes longer. Weighing the pads and keeping track works to show progress even when it feels bad. Few are continent from day one (but it happens) most seems to need a couple of months and a few even longer. But the curve is steep and most of us live with maybe using a pad/day just to be safe for a few months. As I understand it about 10% have bad incontinence issues. And then comes the ED journey. This seems to be very different, some guys no problems, some guys big problems. The only advice I can give is patience, and trying the different medicines that exist. Here is the link to my thread on the surgery if you like to read the more gory details http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...12-Hours-to-go

Posts.Title: Zero Club Membership

Posts.Content: Hello Steve, as I understand it G6 is considered low risk, G7 medium and higher G is unfortunately high risk. This for sure needs to be considered when planning treatment. But remember that the treatment still have a very very good chance of curing. The tables are not really useful for us as individuals as we tend to see ourselves as always being the average. But the tables are based on a large amount of men all with different stories and probably few of them being "average". So they cannot predict what is going to happen to you as an individual. They can advice you on treatment choices. But take one step at a time, and keep track of your PSA after treatment, that is all we can do. And even if your nerves will be gone there are ways of handling that also, others will probably comment on this. Good Luck

Posts.Content: Hi 2b-lucky, and welcome here. You ask a tricky question, as I understand a G6 normally donÂ´t spread outside the prostate. But on the other hand a biopsy can never detect everything going on inside and if it has missed something the closeness to the edge might increase the risk. But I am not a professional, just a guy who had PC. Your data would be useful in advising, as age, PSA history and so on.. I am sure the other guys also will ask where you are been treated, I cannot advice on that since I am in Sweden. Good Luck and take care

Posts.Title: PSA angst....

Posts.Content: Hi Jeff, I agree with Chuck, have a new PSA test taken and do nothing that can irritate the prostate the days before. A very quick spike in PSA can be from other reasons. If it is still high you should take a biopsy and the other tests to see what you are dealing with. Until you know what this is stay away from Dr Google and stay here, this forum is built of guys with similar histories of PC and the advice you get here is balanced and experience based. This place will help you through the waiting. Good Luck

Posts.Title: The Waiting is the hardest Part

Posts.Content: Hi wbigs, and welcome to the club. DonÂ´t worry too much, with a PSA of 3 it is very probable that this is contained and you have plenty of time to make a plan. And the plan will be made very much based on your own preference/fears. Basically you can choose between surgery and radiation, both with the same success rates. The younger you are the more speaks for surgery, you can handle it well, you get to know what is in there after the pathology. Radiation however have fewer immediate side-effects but as you are young those side-effects will sneak up on you sooner or later. The third alternative is just to watch this and act when the PSA is at a certain level, this buys you some time without side-effects. It is a devils choice but if you read the stories here you will see that many guys pass through with very few problems. But also for sure some donÂ´t. For now you should be aware of the fact that you are not in a hurry, do get educated and find a surgeon/onchologist you trust and do ask your questions here. Good Luck

Posts.Title: 18 month results.

Posts.Content: Hello Guys, I donÂ´t post much nowadays, but I still hang around now and then. Also I see that many of the guys active 4 years ago have left but still I would like to wish you all a Happy new Year. And a special Thanks to Chuck and Michael F who have helped so many. I think that many of us who have been somewhat lucky with side-effects and stuff tend to not post but here goes. I had surgery exactly 4 years ago, leakage was a small issue and only a problem for a couple of months, now it is not an issue. ED was more persistent and for a period I was quite depressed by it but to my surprise and joy it is still improving and for the last 6 months it has quite drastically improved, so the famous nerves heal for a very long time indeed. So what I am trying to say to all of you who feel depressed by ED is that keep the faith, it will improve. Good Luck and thanks to all of You who supported me.

Posts.Title: My First Zero came today

Posts.Content: Hello Brava, I also have one metal hip and my surgeon said there was no point of a MRI since the picture gets very distorted so they did not do it. I had the surgery anyway and for me it went fine. Nerves spared, cancer free after one year and very little incontinence. As I understand it the surgeon takes the decision on nerve-sparing when he actually sees the prostate during surgery and if there is no visible tumor he can go ahead. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Metal Hips, MRI and the Woody

Posts.Content: Hello and welcome to the forum. He will need some help for about a week, the catheter is a problem to move around with and he will have problems getting up from and into the bed. He will be sore and bloated and have some pain. It is probably better to sleep alone just because you sleep poorly and move around a lot, also here the catheter is always in the way. But after a week he probably can take care of himself, maybe sooner. He will need to eat food that gets his stomach going, prune juice for example. On tips for the day before surgery......well it is all kind of dirty....(sorry about that) DonÂ´t worry, this will be over in a short time. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Advice for after care

Posts.Content: Well a steel hip will make radiation a little more complicated since the beams cannot be pointed as normally but there are other ways to do it. Having said that this is the reason I am waiting with surgery on my second hip. I will be forced to fix it at some point of time but I would like to wait so I am a little more certain that the cancer is gone. My surgeon says that I should change the hip now since being able to exercise has a higher value than the risk of complicated radiation. The agony of choice......

Posts.Content: Hello Rick, and congratulations on the downgrade. The urge to urinate took some days for me to come back, before that I went rather often. The Kegels sure are important but donÂ´t overdo it, that might make it worse. The first step for many is to get dry over a night, and then during walks and finally during strange moves or sneezing. I weighed my pads but only to try to track if I was getting better, and it helped me because sometimes it felt hopeless and then the curve could show me that I was getting better after all. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Getting ready for RALP, what do I need onhand?

Posts.Content: Hello Don, and welcome to our little club. I had similar data as you however not such a long record. Statistics does not really help you at this point what does help you is your long record which says that whatever is happening in there is not happening fast. And very often PC is not fast so the best you can do is to try to relax since you are not in a big hurry, and get educated. Read the stickies on top here and read the stories of the other guys which is a big help. Good luck and keep posting

Posts.Title: 2 1/2 year PSA results in

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 Quark cheese and flax seed oil??? PLEASE! This supposed "cure" has been around for more than sixty years and is touted as "the cancer cure that the medical community doesn't want anybody to know about". During those sixty years, not one study has proven this diet effective at curing cancer or anything else. Maybe it can cure dandruff... Hi Jim, actually you are spot on, flax seed is used on horses with poor fur, and women take it to get better hair. It also is good if you have a slow stomach and need to get things moving. But that is also all it does. Quark is good if you want to loose weight and are used to eat a lot of ice-cream.... All these diets may do good BEFORE you get cancer, but when the cancer is there it will not do anything at all about that.

Posts.Title: Advice for after care

Posts.Content: Hi Ron, did you also get a freePSA result? I am a Swede and I know that the procedure here differs a bit from USA but here they use the freePSA as an indicator to do a biopsy. But I would guess a new PSA first of all and probably then a DRE and then maybe a biopsy. Having said that none of these steps are anything to worry about. I know there are some differences of opinion here but I found that what took the worst hit was my dignity.... As the others say take one step at a time and try not to worry, the "good" thing with prostate cancer is that it most often develops slowly and with a PSA under 10 you still will have time to get educated and make an informed choice. But you are far from that yet, take a new PSA first of all. Good Luck and try not to worry too much

Posts.Title: Made my choice today

Posts.Content: Hello Don, and welcome to our little club. I had similar data as you however not such a long record. Statistics does not really help you at this point what does help you is your long record which says that whatever is happening in there is not happening fast. And very often PC is not fast so the best you can do is to try to relax since you are not in a big hurry, and get educated. Read the stickies on top here and read the stories of the other guys which is a big help. Good luck and keep posting

Posts.Title: 9 month post-surgery update

Posts.Content: Hello and welcome to the forum. He will need some help for about a week, the catheter is a problem to move around with and he will have problems getting up from and into the bed. He will be sore and bloated and have some pain. It is probably better to sleep alone just because you sleep poorly and move around a lot, also here the catheter is always in the way. But after a week he probably can take care of himself, maybe sooner. He will need to eat food that gets his stomach going, prune juice for example. On tips for the day before surgery......well it is all kind of dirty....(sorry about that) DonÂ´t worry, this will be over in a short time. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Jeff's post op thread.

Posts.Content: Hi NW, the incontinence improvement comes in steps. And unfortunately sometimes it can feel like a step in the wrong direction. You should measure progress weekly not daily. I donÂ´t think the chainsaw work had any effect on incontinence. How much does he leak? If he is using pads try measure the weight and keep track of that because that will show the improvement even if it feels bad. I did this and it helped to see that it did improve even when it felt bad. I also guess that as he feels better he also starts moving around more and this can cause more leaks, for example walking and spitting, sneezing, hugging, all these can cause a small leak. I think you should tell him that he seems to experience what many of us have experienced and that it is normal. On ED you really should not get nervous for at least 6 months. I am sorry to say this but I think that it is important to realize that ED can be an issue for many months but it will get better and also you should try the pills and other stuff because it will sooner or later work. DonÂ´t give up. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Hitting a platform

Posts.Content: Hello Wife, I had exactly the same, basically my stomach shut down. Nothing passed. I had to stay for six days in hospital, on the fifth day I couldnÂ´t eat any more, i actually threw up when I ate, I guess I was full. But on day five gas started to pass and on day six I was sent home and slowly things got better. My surgeon said that this happens now and then and that it is a combination of the surgery messing up your bowels and the painkillers making you constipated. It is really painful. The pain from the holes in my stomach and the catheter was really nothing at all compared to the bowel issues. What finally worked for me was walking, I was fine in all other respects so I walked round and round the ward and slowly things started happening. But it was very slow. The surgeon also told me that they did not want to send me home until either gas or else had passed since there may be "something else going on" but he never told me what that might be. I donÂ´t have any real advice more than walking and trying to move around but you should tell him that this has happened to others also. I really feel for him, to others it sounds like a ridiculous thing but it is really painful. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Husband had DaVinci 1/5/16

Posts.Content: He will be much better after that happened. The sore spots is normal, he has had 5 holes in his stomach and it will hurt for a while but soon get better. He should not lift anything even slightly heavy and he should certainly not twist while lifting. (but that will hurt so it is kind of self-regulating). DonÂ´t worry about the recovery, it will be a lot easier from now on. I have had a hip replacement a couple of years ago and even if everybody says that "it is a standard procedure and you can go home after two days and you quickly get back on your legs" for the first week it HURTS. But it soon gets better. And I think it is the same with most major surgery, it quickly gets better but the first days can for some be very rough and we tend to only read and listen to the ones that have a smooth trip so it can be stressful when we are in the middle of pain and discomfort. But it gets better and it gets better very fast so give him a week more and you will hopefully be smiling at all of this.

Posts.Title: Jeff's post op thread.

Posts.Content: Hello MCM_2, Well others are giving good advice, I also suggest a free PSA test beeing done, this indicates cancer if <20%. It is used as a warning in Sweden and was the reason for me to get a biopsy. A 3T MRI also gives better info. The problem is that a biopsy certainly can miss a tumour, it is not a perfect method, and here the free PSA and/or 3T MRI can give more info. I donÂ´t want to sound negative here but I would strongly suggest to track the PSA and free PSA every say three months to catch if there is a trend. If the free PSA is <20 I would get a new biopsy. But that is me, I am just a guy who had PC. Take Care

Posts.Title: Concerned about delaying surgery

Posts.Content: nrhk, I have limited experience of chemo but my mother have multiple myeloma and she has taken two series of really hard chemo, basically they gave all she could take in order to do a stem-cell transplant. What she told me is that the nausea you get used to, however the chemo caused side-effects as virus infections, herpes wounds, teeth problems and other. I donÂ´t mean to scare you but I would like to tell that she said it was totally worth it since it prolonged her life and when the chemo stopped she quickly became better. She said that support from us was important and just to let her vent and complain about it all was important. So remember that chemo will prolong life and even if it is a pain while taking it, life quick gets better when it stops. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Jeff's post op thread.

Posts.Content: Hi Ron, did you also get a freePSA result? I am a Swede and I know that the procedure here differs a bit from USA but here they use the freePSA as an indicator to do a biopsy. But I would guess a new PSA first of all and probably then a DRE and then maybe a biopsy. Having said that none of these steps are anything to worry about. I know there are some differences of opinion here but I found that what took the worst hit was my dignity.... As the others say take one step at a time and try not to worry, the "good" thing with prostate cancer is that it most often develops slowly and with a PSA under 10 you still will have time to get educated and make an informed choice. But you are far from that yet, take a new PSA first of all. Good Luck and try not to worry too much

Posts.Title: What to do if PSA Level is High

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear about the diagnosis, as the others have said he needs to do something and sooner probably than later. I guess he already had a biopsy and that the G7 was identified by it. His PSA is high but I have seen way worse also. You can see this as a "glass half full"-situation since the cancer has been identified and you can act on it compared to having missed it for couple of years more. As the others have said this type of cancer have good chances of a cure but you should hit it hard and good right now, maybe with both surgery and radiation (but your doctors will know best) And concerning diets and other methods they are fine before you get the cancer, to decrease the odds of getting it, but (and I cannot stress this enough) they are not a cure when the cancer is there. But there are still lots of things your husband should do, he should try to get as fit as ever possible before the treatment because then it will be easier to get through it, he should get educated on prostate cancer (that reduces anxiety and stress) and you should talk about it together. Apart from when my children was born, the period of handling cancer was the period when me and my wife was as closest and even if the reason was bad, it felt really good. Good Luck and feel free to ask any questions. You will soon realize that the people in here are not shy or too concerned about dignity..

Posts.Content: Welcome back Jeff, The first week can be rough in some ways, gas problems, catheter problems and so on but for most of us it is way better after about a week. Take it easy and try to relax, donÂ´t lift stuff. I can imagine having a puppy can be a challenge with a catheter, we have a 12 weeks schnauzer and it is quite enough without it. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Jeff's post op thread.

Posts.Content: Hello MCM_2, Well others are giving good advice, I also suggest a free PSA test beeing done, this indicates cancer if <20%. It is used as a warning in Sweden and was the reason for me to get a biopsy. A 3T MRI also gives better info. The problem is that a biopsy certainly can miss a tumour, it is not a perfect method, and here the free PSA and/or 3T MRI can give more info. I donÂ´t want to sound negative here but I would strongly suggest to track the PSA and free PSA every say three months to catch if there is a trend. If the free PSA is <20 I would get a new biopsy. But that is me, I am just a guy who had PC. Take Care

Posts.Title: OK all, so I had my first post-op PSA blood draw yesterday

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear about the diagnosis, as the others have said he needs to do something and sooner probably than later. I guess he already had a biopsy and that the G7 was identified by it. His PSA is high but I have seen way worse also. You can see this as a "glass half full"-situation since the cancer has been identified and you can act on it compared to having missed it for couple of years more. As the others have said this type of cancer have good chances of a cure but you should hit it hard and good right now, maybe with both surgery and radiation (but your doctors will know best) And concerning diets and other methods they are fine before you get the cancer, to decrease the odds of getting it, but (and I cannot stress this enough) they are not a cure when the cancer is there. But there are still lots of things your husband should do, he should try to get as fit as ever possible before the treatment because then it will be easier to get through it, he should get educated on prostate cancer (that reduces anxiety and stress) and you should talk about it together. Apart from when my children was born, the period of handling cancer was the period when me and my wife was as closest and even if the reason was bad, it felt really good. Good Luck and feel free to ask any questions. You will soon realize that the people in here are not shy or too concerned about dignity..

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed.....

Posts.Content: Hello Sandra, The PSA of 10 and a G3+4 in 7 samples of 18 is not good, but not very bad either. To me it sounds like the cyst is not really connected to the prostate cancer, I never heard of anything like that. The PC as such is very treatable and a cure should be possible with surgery or radiation. But I am not a doctor, just a guy who had PC. It sound like your doctors want to check the cyst first and then recommend a treatment and this sound wise to me. PC is a waiting game and tough to handle, but to me it sounds like your doctors are on track. I am sorry that you have to handle this but this forum is the right place to be and I am sure others will give further advice. Good luck and take care
