Posts.Title: Just diagnosed.....

Posts.Content: OTS, sounds perfectly normal. The cases you mention where you leak will one by one go away as time goes by. Worst for me was raising from a chair and strangely enough when i squeezed my wifes butt. One trick to measure progress is to weigh your pads and you will see that the amount decreases day by day. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Question for you DRY guys post RP

Posts.Content: My surgeon actually did a Rocco stitch but it failed to close correctly so he had to redo it with a traditional stitch (whatever that is...) But it worked perfectly fine, I have only had minor incontinence and no bleeding to talk about so I guess it worked without the Rocco-stitch. Sorry to hear about your wife, but early detection is always better than late, even if it is a poor comfort.

Posts.Title: 2nd. Zero report!!!

Posts.Content: Hello Fred, Well the facts are that your doctors are probably right, it takes longer time, both the incontinence and the ED. But I know the frustration and the panic can be strong at times. For me it took a year to get it to work but before that it was pretty much no sex at all. We tried a couple of times but it was not very good (too floppy). But now after 17 months we finally made it so that both me and Mrs could enjoy it. The earth did not move but still.... The worst part is when you stop believing that it will get better, that is when panic enters. But it will get better. Keep trying on your own, and maybe try Muse or injections. But donÂ´t give up, you are very early out yet. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed.....

Posts.Content: I am no expert on docetaxel but my mother had tough chemo for her multiple myeloma when she was around 70 and she was not well at all. Chemo has side-effects and sometimes the dosage is set based on an estimate what the individual can cope with because the more the better. At least that was her situation. I still remember when she called me and cried. I am sorry about your father being put through this but I would try to get an answer from the oncologist on exactly what to expect from side-effects. Goos Luck

AgeInfo.Phrase: myeloma when she was around 70 and she was not well

Posts.Title: Pathology report is back -- Relief!

Posts.Content: Hi Pratoman, It is not the same down there. For me I am still sore in the lowest part of the uretra, I guess after the catheter. Also I think I can feel that the urine bladder is not in the same place, it feels different when it is full. I can also feel a difference in the bowels. I still have way more gas than before and get bloated very easy. When this happens it hurts in the lower bowels in a new way. It is not very painful, just a new sensation. My urine stream is stronger (which makes sense). And there still is pain in the general surgical area when I lift something. Not bad but it is there very often. All this now and then freaks me out but I guess it is normal. They did mess around rather much in there.

Posts.Title: Pathology report is back -- Relief!

Posts.Content: Hello Logic1, I was diagnosed 8 weeks ago and had similar G-score and staging as you. I will go for surgery on jan 7th. I do not have any experience to offer however what made me choose as I did was as many have stated here the wider opportunities if further treatment is needed. I also like the fact that you will get a detailed analysis of the cancer afterwards. It is a difficult choice and a lousy christmas gift to get but good luck to you. Wilde

Posts.Title: Must decide between surgery and radiation

Posts.Content: I am no expert on docetaxel but my mother had tough chemo for her multiple myeloma when she was around 70 and she was not well at all. Chemo has side-effects and sometimes the dosage is set based on an estimate what the individual can cope with because the more the better. At least that was her situation. I still remember when she called me and cried. I am sorry about your father being put through this but I would try to get an answer from the oncologist on exactly what to expect from side-effects. Goos Luck

AgeInfo.Phrase: myeloma when she was around 70 and she was not well

Posts.Title: Is Cialis right for me??

Posts.Content: Hello Tom, You are not alone in the agony of choice, I think most of us instinctively try to avoid surgery at first. It is invasive, it will hurt, there are side-effects no man wants and so on.... But remember a few things: 1. You are probably not in a hurry with a G6 and relatively low PSA, take your time to decide, read the stickies here and ask your questions. 2. Both surgery and radiation have similar success rates 3. With surgery the side-effects hit from day one and then gets better and better, with radiation it is the opposite which speaks for surgery if you are relatively young, radiation if not. 4. With surgery you get a detailed analysis of your tumor afterwards, biopsies are now and then incorrect 5. With surgery you get a second shot with radiation if the cancer reoccurs. By now you can guess what choice I made. But to be honest then I would say that I am happy with the results so far in getting the cancer out. Incontinence was only a minor issue for me, after a couple of months I was fine. ED is still an issue but it works with Viagra. I am now 53 years old. My tumor was a G7 and quite large so if I would have chosen radiation I would have been forced to do both seeds and external radiation and actually the side-effects from that scared me more. Try not to worry too much, you can fix this and a G6 can certainly be cured. Your first prio should be to get rid of the cancer and get cured. Whatever you choose try to get a surgeon/onchologist who are experienced and who you trust. Get a second opinion and read the stories here. When you have chosen donÂ´t lock back. Good Luck and donÂ´t hesitate to ask questions.

Posts.Title: Diagnosed Recently

Posts.Content: Hello Leach, Most important you are a T2 which is good. I also have a ductal component in my report and in Sweden that is always defined as a G4. As I understand it ductal is not common and there is not as much knowledge on it as on normal adenocarcinoma so in order to be cautious it is always a G4. I try not to think too much about it, the important thing is the T2. But do ask your surgeon, and I would be grateful if you post what he say, there is not much info on ductal adenocarcinoma available. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Finally looked at my pathology report

Posts.Content: It is tricky, I mean someone has to be those first 300? In Sweden they work in teams, one experienced and one learning and they do the surgery somehow together. It is also considered more important here that the surgeon performs a certain amount of surgeries/years than the total number. It makes kind of sense. The minimum should be >25/year which is really minimum. The guy that did surgery on me performs more than 50/year, often 6/week.

Posts.Content: NW, take it easy, even if nerves are spared they are badly treated and numb for a long time. I am about your mans age and it took a year to get back. And by get back I mean it works as before with Viagra. I think that many try too much too soon after surgery and get depressed. And believe me after 6 months I was really depressed also. But patience my friend, is a virtue and it will get better. Good Luck and take care

Try not to worry too much, you can fix this and a G6 can certainly be cured. Your first prio should be to get rid of the cancer and get cured. Whatever you choose try to get a surgeon/onchologist who are experienced and who you trust. Get a second opinion and read the stories here. When you have chosen donÂ´t lock back. Posts.Title: MRI results

Posts.Content: Hi David, You are on the right track, it is 50/50 between surgery and radiation. But get a second opinion is always a good thing. Whichever you choose you want to find a good radiation guy/surgeon that you trust and that can give good info on side-effects. The big differences are basically that with surgery you get all the negative things immediately and then it gets better, it hurts and you get more or less incontinent and impotent from day 1 but then it improves and for many of us in 12-24 months you are basically fine. You also get a detailed biopsy report on what type of cancer you had which has a value. With radiation the treatment normally is much less painful but takes a longer time and the side-effects appear way later but gets worse and worse with time. It is much about your personal preference and which doctor you trust. Good Luck

Posts.Title: First Post Bummed newbie

Posts.Content: NW, take it easy, even if nerves are spared they are badly treated and numb for a long time. I am about your mans age and it took a year to get back. And by get back I mean it works as before with Viagra. I think that many try too much too soon after surgery and get depressed. And believe me after 6 months I was really depressed also. But patience my friend, is a virtue and it will get better. Good Luck and take care

Posts.Title: Hoping to hear from the partners

Posts.Content: I thought of HD Brachy seriously when I got PC. However my tumor was of the size that the radiation lady told me that I would need both Brachy and external beam radiation and that made me go the other direction. It was really good to sit down with both a surgeon and a radiation specialist at the same time and walk through the pros and cons. Also my wife was there which was good. For me for some reason surgery just was less scary.

Posts.Title: HD Brachy Monotherapy: My choice & my experience

Posts.Content: Maverick, I did this: I told my wife immediately and then after the biopsy confirmed the PC I told my daughters, mother, relatives....I kind of pulled a band aid and just called everybody I care about in a day. It took some energy. At work I did this, I am a manager over about 50 and I have every friday an "information coffee break" where I inform about all kinds of issues and the group can ask questions. I just stood there in front of them and said "I have &%€#% cancer, and I &%€#"# hate it" it was emotional but after that everybody knew and there was little or no gossip going on. I wanted to tell and I wanted people to talk to me and to ask how I was. So that worked for me. But this is a personal decision.

In a way, it would be easier to have some other type of cancer. Yeah, I only say that I have PC, then if someone ask I can talk about what that means. I have a few friends which I tell it all to, all the gory details, and then we can laugh about it. But they are very few.

Posts.Title: And On It Goes

Posts.Content: Hi Paddy and welcome here. I have no experience from a G9 and as the others have stated you probably should hit it good and hard from day one. As I understood it from my discussions (in Sweden) the higher the G-score the stronger the argument for doing radiation as first treatment. The argument being that higher G-scores often need follow up radiation after surgery anyway. On the other hand some argue that you should take away the bulk of the tumor to increase the odds of success. I strongly recommend you to listen to both a surgeon and an radiation oncologist and find one you feel you can trust. At the end of the day the trust and the personal belief in treatment is what will make the choice. Take care and Good Luck

Posts.Title: I am in the zero club!!!!!

Posts.Content: Hello BrightSky, I am sorry about your uncles situation. Chuck is giving you good advice. If you read some of the posts here you will see that most of us have had cancer but we are not doctors just guys, the other thing is that we tend to not sugarcoat anything since we all in som point of time really wanted to know what is going on. So I am sorry to sound blunt but your uncle needs treatment and he needs it now. Even if the latest peak in PSA may be caused by something else he is still living with a diagnosed PC and PSA >20 which means he is in a real hurry. I donÂ´t know why he did not get treatment sooner, maybe he did not want it, maybe his doctor did not explain good enough, but the good thing is that his oncologist says it is still curable. I also think that he wants to hit it with all he got which is hormones and radiation. My guess would be that with a PSA >20 he believes that the tumor may be somewhat outside the prostate but still not metastased and if so surgery is a waste of time and effort since radiation will be needed anyway in that case. So maybe the road of hormones and radiation is a very wise choice. But it would for sure be a good idea to get a second opinion. But please do not waste too much time. Once again I apologize if I sound blunt but I would like to send a sense of urgency to your uncle. Good Luck and keep posting

Posts.Title: PSA rising - any feedback much appreciated

Posts.Content: Hi SeaCock, And welcome, I donÂ´t want to be negative here but on ED you probably need some patience. I have spared nerves on one side, on the other "partly" spared. I am pretty much exactly one year from surgery (and actually when I think about it exactly on the day one year from my last normal sex!) and today it works ok with Viagra but it took about 8 months to get close. The peeing will soon be gone but for sure leaking during sex is one of the last incontinence issues to master. I can still now and then feel a small squirt just by squeezing my wife's butt.... My point with this is: donÂ´t give up. It will come back. It is also easy to actually lose the appetite for sex, (it is just not the same with a half erection and pee leaking.....) I would NEVER have thought that would happen to me before the cancer, but to a certain extent it has. But that is also getting better and better. I wish you a successful recovery

Posts.Title: New Memeber- Had My Da Vinci Surgery 12/11/20105

Posts.Content: Hi Bernard, Your words could have been written by me 18 months ago. It is such a relief to get rid of the cancer and the incontinence that for a period you feel great. But then ED comes sneaking up, and it is as you say, it sucks the joy out of you. And it is depressing. But for me it took 12 months to be somewhat ok and honestly it took until now to get close to before. But now I am there and it is not depressing me anymore. So try to be patient, try Viagra and the other helps, they will help sooner or later. Also Muse could be worth a try. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Post surgery questions now.

Posts.Content: Hello Joe, and welcome. PSA can fluctuate, mine varied up and down between 5.4 and 6.5 in two months. I would not freak out yet, maybe you should take a new test rather soon. However (and remember I am not a doctor, just a prostate cancer guy) since you are young and have 4 of 12 identified as cancer I would go for a treatment and a cure right now. I am sorry to say this. Especially if your PSA stays >10. Take your time to study side-effects and find a urologist or oncologist that you trust. There are several threads here as well as the stickies at the top which all have good information. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed - help?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by JimBow I'm finding it hard to talk about it with anyone, because prostate cancer deals with touchy subjects like sexual function and urination. In a way, it would be easier to have some other type of cancer. Yeah, I only say that I have PC, then if someone ask I can talk about what that means. I have a few friends which I tell it all to, all the gory details, and then we can laugh about it. But they are very few.

Posts.Title: Two 1/2 years after Dai Vinci

Posts.Content: Hi Hopper, donÂ´t buy too much. As the others have said you donÂ´t need it until catheter removal day but I used a small pad before because it can leak a little also while having the catheter. I bought way too much and also got a supply from the hospital so I ended up giving a large bag of stuff back at my last visit. You cannot know what you need until catheter removal day, some guys leak a little some a lot. DonÂ´t worry you will be fine.

Posts.Title: 2 more days before surgery

Posts.Content: Hi Trinity, The others have all given you the pros and cons so I will just give my view: You need treatment and you need it sooner than later. At 59 I would do surgery since you will handle the side-effects in the beginning and not have a gradual decline (You are too young to avoid this). The important thing is to get an experienced surgeon, this will reduce side-effects. But remember this is MY unprofessional view and I am sure there are differences of opinion which I really respect. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Long Time No Talk!

Posts.Content: This might not help you Americans at all but my catheter bags had a hose integrated and just connected to the catheter. The leg bag was a flexible "tube" that went on your thigh and had a pocket where the bag went. All very flexible. It worked like a charm but when you forgot to empty the bag and bent your leg it would squeeze the pee out of the bottom valve. Filled my slipper like that once... It seems to me like there are several solutions to catheter bags, some work well some not so much. What I am getting at is that it may be worth to check for different brands of bags

Posts.Title: Post surgery questions now.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Sometimes I almost feel guilty when relating the relatively "easy" post-op experience I enjoyed. And yet, it's important to mention it, from time to time, because it IS one of the possible experiences of recovery and it might be helpful to those going in with lots of fear. Chuck, it is a double-edged sword. Some guys have a smooth journey and some absolutely not. But I think all stories needs to be told for the guys starting their PC trip. With the risk that some of them are disappointed but some surprised at how smoothly it went. We were two guys having surgery the same morning in my hospital. The other guy went home the day after wearing JEANS, that is actually true. Very little pain for him. I stayed for 6 days...

Posts.Title: Finally the one year < mark.

Posts.Content: Hi Bricks, I took Cialis 5mg fro the first months after surgery, this did not create any erections, but it is supposed to avoid the dreaded shrinkage. I tried Muse, which works but hurts and is a bother (you should use a condom because if Muse leaks into the lady parts she will hurt also and be very unhappy...) Now after 8 months I have stopped the Cialis and I work fine if I take a viagra. It is still getting better and I truly believe that I will get back to needing nothing at some point but I am fine with the Viagra. You need some patient in the ED game.. Good Luck

Posts.Title: New Diagnosis

Posts.Content: Hello BrightSky, I am sorry about your uncles situation. Chuck is giving you good advice. If you read some of the posts here you will see that most of us have had cancer but we are not doctors just guys, the other thing is that we tend to not sugarcoat anything since we all in som point of time really wanted to know what is going on. So I am sorry to sound blunt but your uncle needs treatment and he needs it now. Even if the latest peak in PSA may be caused by something else he is still living with a diagnosed PC and PSA >20 which means he is in a real hurry. I donÂ´t know why he did not get treatment sooner, maybe he did not want it, maybe his doctor did not explain good enough, but the good thing is that his oncologist says it is still curable. I also think that he wants to hit it with all he got which is hormones and radiation. My guess would be that with a PSA >20 he believes that the tumor may be somewhat outside the prostate but still not metastased and if so surgery is a waste of time and effort since radiation will be needed anyway in that case. So maybe the road of hormones and radiation is a very wise choice. But it would for sure be a good idea to get a second opinion. But please do not waste too much time. Once again I apologize if I sound blunt but I would like to send a sense of urgency to your uncle. Good Luck and keep posting

Posts.Title: What to Believe?

Posts.Content: Hello SW, Sorry to hear about your problems. I agree with ASA, you have had a higher than normal PSA for some time and a low fPSA which is indicative of PC, but certainly not proof. As I understand it you already had a biopsy that was negative for PC, have you had a second opinion on that biopsy? might be an idea. But your urologists plan seems to be very good. You certainly need to know what is going on in there. I donÂ´t know anything about PCA3 so I cannot comment on that but a MR guided biopsy should find any suspicious things in there. DonÂ´t worry, you have a plan and that is the best you can do. Good Luck

Posts.Title: My Free/Total PSA Results

Posts.Content: Hello Mark, And welcome here, there are tonnes of experience from prostate surgery here and you already have been given good advice and if you also read the stickies you will get more. You mentioned that you never have had surgery before and it is probably easier to worry without a reference. I had experience from a hip replacement surgery before my prostate surgery so I was a little knowing what to expect. And compared to that the prostate surgery is not bad at all. You should expect to feel bad for a couple of days but it is days not weeks. Pain can be handled but not to 100% and bloating, bladder spasms, shoulder pains etc may happen. But very few have all of them and some (Chuck for example) have no issues whatsoever. If that will be the case for you it is good but in average we all have some issues. The important thing here is that after 2-6 days you will be basically fine. If the direct discomfort after surgery is calculated in days (or for some hours) the next hurdle is incontinence and here we are in average talking about weeks. But doing Kegels and keeping track will show progress and even if it is a negative experience it is not painful. I say this with all respect to the guys who suffer from long incontinence but my point is that it is not physically painful as the pain caused by the surgery as such. And when we talk about ED you can expect to count months instead of weeks. Once again I know that many are more lucky and some are not but on average months. But this also can be fixed with different methods. So donÂ´t worry too much, the surgery is not bad. It is not fun but it will be ok after a few days. And looking back it really was over quickly and normal life came back for me I would say after five weeks. Good Luck

Posts.Title: 2.5 years post surgery; Update

Posts.Content: @Mike: You are right, and I also have had this at every surgery however not as bad as this time. For me the softeners does nothing since the problem is that the bowels just stop working. Walking helped after the prostate surgery however that is tricky after a hip-replacement. @Michael: Plumbing now solved and rehab ongoing, the surgeon has signed a three month sick-leave which I will use to some extend. Pain after a hip replacement is only bad for a couple of days, now it is just sore and I can manage fine hobbling around on crutches annoying my wife.

Posts.Title: Hip replacement done (Off-topic but not 100%)

Posts.Content: This might not help you Americans at all but my catheter bags had a hose integrated and just connected to the catheter. The leg bag was a flexible "tube" that went on your thigh and had a pocket where the bag went. All very flexible. It worked like a charm but when you forgot to empty the bag and bent your leg it would squeeze the pee out of the bottom valve. Filled my slipper like that once... It seems to me like there are several solutions to catheter bags, some work well some not so much. What I am getting at is that it may be worth to check for different brands of bags

Posts.Title: Post Op Rant

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Sometimes I almost feel guilty when relating the relatively "easy" post-op experience I enjoyed. And yet, it's important to mention it, from time to time, because it IS one of the possible experiences of recovery and it might be helpful to those going in with lots of fear. Chuck, it is a double-edged sword. Some guys have a smooth journey and some absolutely not. But I think all stories needs to be told for the guys starting their PC trip. With the risk that some of them are disappointed but some surprised at how smoothly it went. We were two guys having surgery the same morning in my hospital. The other guy went home the day after wearing JEANS, that is actually true. Very little pain for him. I stayed for 6 days...

Posts.Content: Hi jlynn, For me the bloating got worse for about a week, and it took one more for it to go away. Swollen ankles are also common after surgery and as Chuck say it has probably to do with sitting in the car for a long time, but keep an eye on it and if it gets worse or causes pain call the hospital. It takes at least a week to be somewhat ok after the surgery, it is a mayor surgery after all. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Post-op question

Posts.Content: My personal theory is that there is no physical shrinkage but with your nerves bruised or cut the blood flow to your penis is close to none, so your poor penis is in the stage of "after ice-bath" all the time. It has not really shrunk, it is terrified. I eat cialis 5mg every day which does not give any erections but it has increased the blood flow to the normal level which means that my penis looks like it used to do. Good enough for me

Posts.Title: Shrinkage following DaVinci

Posts.Content: Hi Trinity, The others have all given you the pros and cons so I will just give my view: You need treatment and you need it sooner than later. At 59 I would do surgery since you will handle the side-effects in the beginning and not have a gradual decline (You are too young to avoid this). The important thing is to get an experienced surgeon, this will reduce side-effects. But remember this is MY unprofessional view and I am sure there are differences of opinion which I really respect. Good Luck

Posts.Title: I'm back, with less than great news

Posts.Content: Hello wbigs and welcome here. There are good and bad things with getting PC at a young age, the good is that you have discovered it early and can fix it. The bad is that you can probably not "outlive" it, you will need to do something at some point. I was recommended surgery partly since I was also young and would be able to handle it well. The good thing is that you can for sure cure this, either with surgery or radiation. Good Luck

Posts.Title: I'm back, with less than great news

Posts.Content: Brian, I guess I was lucky on this issue, after 7 weeks I am almost continent, small squirts on surprised laughter etc. 1 thin shield/day. I have noticed during my period that things improved in steps and some of them happened quickly. For example leaking getting out of the car stopped over a day, then nothing happens during a period. Also it is very individual, I would recommend doing the kegels, for me it felt as if the muscles "woke up" when I did kegels. So what I am trying to say is that even if it is a marathon improvements now and then happen quickly.

Posts.Title: Incontinence Exp

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman Everyone is different and every experience is different, I am 7 weeks out from RALP. I have been fully continent (meaning no pads, but just a squirt here and there, mostly stress related, not enough to need to wear anything). BUT.... Tonight, lying in bed, watching TV, I fell asleep for about 40 minutes. Suddenly, I woke up, and realized that I was wet. VERY wet. Soaked thru my briefs and gym shorts. There was even a small wet spot in the blanket covering me. WTH? I had a strong urge to pee, and got up, was able to control it, then, when in the bathroom,took the longest pee I've taken since the catheter came out No idea where this came from, I guess I'm not really continent. Very frustrating, and scary. Anyone experience this? Strange things happen, this morning I got out of bed and into the bathroom, stripped naked and stood in front of a mirror and stretched my arms upwards and to my horror saw pee running out on the floor. Felt nothing.......

Posts.Title: Incontinence Exp

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by jorola No you read right on the numbers and no he has not had surgery. His dr told him that surgery would most likely cause the cancer to become super aggressive and did not recommend it. He also said by no surgery he would have 10 to 12 good years. He is currently 67. Hi Jorola, I am no expert but that sounds a little strange, His PSA is high but in no way extreme, and it is moving around a little but it does not seem to rise quickly. He is only 67 there is no reason as I can see whatsoever to not treat it. Has he had any scans showing the cancer has spread? If not I would check that and also get a second opinion from an expert. But I donÂ´t know your fathers doctor or the results from the biopsy which may indicate something else. I strongly recommend you get those results. I also know how stubborn old men can get when it comes to their health and at some point it gets to you even if you are the strong and silent type of guy so maybe it is just wearing him down. My father although older is just like that. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Just checking in

Posts.Content: Hello Anwank, I was a little older than your husband and also had a little more aggressive cancer and I went for surgery. The important thing to remember is that prostate cancer will give your masculinity a hit, but you can take it with a little support. It felt like crap after surgery while recovering and being incontinent and impotent but it gets better, and also it is a psychological struggle to get over cancer, but it is certainly doable with a little support. My advice to you is to be patient with him and try to remember and tell him that things get better and all the negative stuff will go away. He may be depressed and moody but it will get better. And time flies, today I am basically fine and it feels like cancer never happened. Try to be patient and positive Good luck

Posts.Title: Advice: How to support my partner the most

Posts.Content: Hi Gary, I was diagnosed with G7 in october and was in shock of course. The advice you are given here are excellent and given by guys who are experienced so you are in the right place. The two things that stuck in me which helped a lot was: 1. You are not in a hurry, you have the time to make an informed decision, but with G7 you need to make a decision 2. Talk to an urologist AND an oncologist and if you do not have confidence in them find another. You need input from both sides. Good luck

Posts.Title: New guy. Just a week ago, I thought male pattern baldness was my main aging concern.

Posts.Content: Hi, I had my surgery in January and was pretty much continent 6 weeks later. Now 6 months later I really have no incontinence issues apart from the fact that when I have to go, I have to go now. That is no issues but one, and it is stupid. Living in Sweden I am right now on a 5 week vacation and having spent a lot of time with my wife I have noticed that every single time I hug her and maybe squeezes her ass in a loving way I squirt. Every time...And it is embarrassing since she notices how I kind of freeze mid-hug and goes to the bathroom. It is really messy when it happens wearing swim-shorts. Due to ED we have not really tried to have sex yet but now I am getting a little concerned that I will just start squirting uncontrolled if we try it. Well since dignity is way behind me I am not that concerned but just wanted to ask if any of you guys have also experienced this little problem?

Posts.Title: Good Luck Highlander

Posts.Content: Hi Bernard, and Good Luck, a few things that may help: shoes that are easy to walk into, you will have a problem bending and tying a shoe. Also headphones and some kind of music player or iPad can be good if you are in a shared room and have to stay for more than one night. I was with 4 other guys and man they could snore and talk in their sleep. Apart from that I guess you get what you need from the hospital. Good Luck and take care. This will be over sooner than you can imagine.

Posts.Title: Major Milestone

Posts.Content: Hi guys, 10 days ago I had a planned hip replacement, all went according to plan but the pain after is really high so I took morphine (oxycontin) to handle it. Since I know that I donÂ´t tolerate it well I took rather low doses and only for 4 days. After 4 days I hadn'tÂ´t pooped at all and the stomach started to swell. Long story short, after 6 days I had to go to the emergency room sick as a dog, they emptied my stomach from both ends and I had a cat-scan and what I had was something called "paralyzed guts" (translating from Swedish here...) which means your bowels stop working and just swell up to finally burst. This can be caused by morphine which was the case for me. And burst bowels is a very bad thing as I understand it. So a small advice to you guys having surgery, if you never had morphine before be aware of your stomachs and if they stop working take it seriously.

Posts.Title: Good Luck Highlander

Posts.Content: Hi, and welcome here, you are in the right place to get information. There are several guys here with similar diagnosis as you, me being one of them. When I made my choice I leaned towards radiation but later changed my mind to surgery mainly because you get an answer weather you are cured quicker and because there is the opportunity to get radiation at a later stage. But that was my reasoning and there are others who reasoned differently and are happy. In either way (as others already have stated) you should try to find an experienced doctor who you also trust. I also think you should remember that with your diagnosis (3+4 confined) you have time to get informed but it does need treatment so when you have decided you probably should not wait. But your doctors can make that judgement better of course. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Finished SRT

Posts.Content: Hi all, just took the energy drink which will be my last meal before surgery tomorrow and also took the Klexane-shot in my bellyfat. Luckily I had a hip-replacement a year ago and know how to take the shots. Also I am quite calm since the pain from the hip-replacement probably was way worse than what tomorrow might throw at me. Packed my bag, loose pants, several underwear, iPad loaded with movies and books. Stored man-pads for several weeks, made guest bed with rubberized sheets, bought prune-juice and all kinds of fruits and soups. Filled car with gas and checked weather for tomorrow. There probably are astronauts less prepared for space..... Thank you all for your advice and support in this forum. See you on the other side.

Posts.Title: 12 Hours to go....

Posts.Content: IÂ´m Baack! Had a bumpy road and came home today after 6 days in hospital. Surgery went well, no issues with bladder spasm and in the wake-up I felt fine, sigh leakage from the catheter but a young nurse rapidly washed my boys and I was fine. The surgen spared the nerves on one side and partly on the other side but given the size of the tumor he was happy. There was a small leak in the suture so I had to have a drain in place. The most remarkable memory was the handwritten note taped on the daVinci robot saying "Do not unplug, batteries will drain!" (True!) However the drain added one day in hospital to check that leakage stopped. But then came the hard part, I bloated severely, my digestive system shut down. Day three I looked pregnant and started vomiting and where given morphine against the pain in the bladder area where gas probably pressed the bruised areas. The drain was removed which did not hurt but felt straight unnatural. Day four a minor fart and more vomiting. Nurses actually at one point said "we can see that you are in such pain that you should take more morphine". No BM but clear fluid. I did walk around as much as possible, I did take laxatives. Day five monumental fart happened after actual doing toe-touches in bathroom and pain stopped however the doctors said that evenso the swelling was so big that if it did not go down I would need an x-ray of my abdomen. However on day five things continued to get out of me and in the evening yesterday I could eat and basically feel ok. Then I also realized that the pain from the surgery as such was very minor. And day six I was released. I recognize the stomach issues from my hip replacement and I believe that this is a side effect of surgery that now and then can happen but with a prostate removal you worry more because the pain is in the same area. So here I sit and watch TV with a bag at my leg and a pregnant stomach but feeling ok.

Posts.Title: 1 Year Anniversary of Surgery & Thoughts

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Marve PDV: Already next day out hospital? Here they hold hospital 10 days! So they told. Or maybe you surgery is different than here? I dont know how they make this? Cut stomach or somehow different? I dont know. Hi Marve, I had the robotic surgery in Sweden in January and I stayed 6 nights in hospital. Catheter in for 2 weeks. This is longer compared to many of the US guys here. I guess the US guys just can take more pain compared to us European softies Good Luck

Posts.Title: First time here

Posts.Content: Hello Steven, I donÂ´t think that any of your issues are typical PC symptoms. I would say that in a young guy like you PC very rarely gives any symptoms at all (but I am no doctor). I was 52 when it was detected and the tumor was quite large and I had no symptoms whatsoever. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Blood in urine 2 weeks post op

Posts.Content: This might not help you Americans at all but my catheter bags had a hose integrated and just connected to the catheter. The leg bag was a flexible "tube" that went on your thigh and had a pocket where the bag went. All very flexible. It worked like a charm but when you forgot to empty the bag and bent your leg it would squeeze the pee out of the bottom valve. Filled my slipper like that once... It seems to me like there are several solutions to catheter bags, some work well some not so much. What I am getting at is that it may be worth to check for different brands of bags

Posts.Content: Hi Bricks, I took Cialis 5mg fro the first months after surgery, this did not create any erections, but it is supposed to avoid the dreaded shrinkage. I tried Muse, which works but hurts and is a bother (you should use a condom because if Muse leaks into the lady parts she will hurt also and be very unhappy...) Now after 8 months I have stopped the Cialis and I work fine if I take a viagra. It is still getting better and I truly believe that I will get back to needing nothing at some point but I am fine with the Viagra. You need some patient in the ED game.. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Why radiation after surgery???

Posts.Content: Hello I pulled my catheter 2 weeks ago. This is what I observed: Nights were dry almost from day one which is good. On burning sensation I had that too, I think it is from irritation from the catheter. Also I had no real sensation of needing to pee, but when it came a couple of days later it was very urgent, basically when it came there was an interval of one minute to get to the bathroom. Pain in the perineum is normal for some time after I think. I was told to do Kegels quite aggressively, three times/day from day one. I know this does not work for everybody but it worked for me. Also on all kinds of muscle tensioning I had to really concentrate not to leak, as sneezing, farting, spitting, raising from chair etc. But if I concentrated and tensioned the muscles it got better at say day 4. From what I have read here everybody have more or less problems in the beginning but it does get better. I would do the Kegels if I were you. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Checking in After Robotic Surgery

Posts.Content: Hello Mark, And welcome here, there are tonnes of experience from prostate surgery here and you already have been given good advice and if you also read the stickies you will get more. You mentioned that you never have had surgery before and it is probably easier to worry without a reference. I had experience from a hip replacement surgery before my prostate surgery so I was a little knowing what to expect. And compared to that the prostate surgery is not bad at all. You should expect to feel bad for a couple of days but it is days not weeks. Pain can be handled but not to 100% and bloating, bladder spasms, shoulder pains etc may happen. But very few have all of them and some (Chuck for example) have no issues whatsoever. If that will be the case for you it is good but in average we all have some issues. The important thing here is that after 2-6 days you will be basically fine. If the direct discomfort after surgery is calculated in days (or for some hours) the next hurdle is incontinence and here we are in average talking about weeks. But doing Kegels and keeping track will show progress and even if it is a negative experience it is not painful. I say this with all respect to the guys who suffer from long incontinence but my point is that it is not physically painful as the pain caused by the surgery as such. And when we talk about ED you can expect to count months instead of weeks. Once again I know that many are more lucky and some are not but on average months. But this also can be fixed with different methods. So donÂ´t worry too much, the surgery is not bad. It is not fun but it will be ok after a few days. And looking back it really was over quickly and normal life came back for me I would say after five weeks. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Newest Member of the Zero Club

Posts.Content: Hello Dom555, It may sound strange but it would be more worrying with PSA 33 and no symptoms whatsoever. A rectal exam normally does not hurt much apart from hurting your dignity. Without being trained in any way I would not worry until after an infection has been ruled out. And then not until a second PSA is high. There is not much good with prostate cancer but one thing is that you very seldom are in a huge hurry, it grows slowly and there is time to get educated and make a decision. Good Luck and try not to worry, plenty of experience to be found in here also for advice.

Posts.Title: Could My Husband Have Prostate Cancer?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman Everyone is different and every experience is different, I am 7 weeks out from RALP. I have been fully continent (meaning no pads, but just a squirt here and there, mostly stress related, not enough to need to wear anything). BUT.... Tonight, lying in bed, watching TV, I fell asleep for about 40 minutes. Suddenly, I woke up, and realized that I was wet. VERY wet. Soaked thru my briefs and gym shorts. There was even a small wet spot in the blanket covering me. WTH? I had a strong urge to pee, and got up, was able to control it, then, when in the bathroom,took the longest pee I've taken since the catheter came out No idea where this came from, I guess I'm not really continent. Very frustrating, and scary. Anyone experience this? Strange things happen, this morning I got out of bed and into the bathroom, stripped naked and stood in front of a mirror and stretched my arms upwards and to my horror saw pee running out on the floor. Felt nothing.......

Posts.Content: Hi, for me the stomach was the big issue, it basically shut down and nothing came out for three days, this may sound as a minor issue but it caused quite some pain in the operated area. Be prepared for pain and you will be surprised if it does not happen. Good Luck

Posts.Title: recooping after surgery

Posts.Content: Wayne, please listen to Chuck he is giving you good advice. And even if your total diagnosis is not the worst in the world you will sooner or later need treatment. It might not be a big hurry but at 62 a 3+4 cancer will certainly have the time needed to kill you. I am sorry to be blunt, I really am. I would strongly suggest to use the time you have to decide on a treatment and enjoy your days without side-effects, but unfortunately there are very few miracles and very few cancers go away. I am a strong believer in a healthy life-style and the good sides of religion, but I also believe that a healthy life-style might decrease the odds of getting cancer but NOT cure it if it occurs. I think this is often mixed for same. I think you should listen to yourself " I have PCa, 4/12 cores positive, 10% PTI (small volume), Gleason score for 3, 3+3 and the forth 3+4" These are the facts. Get another opinion from one of the institutions recommended here, and go from there. Good Luck and keep posting

Posts.Title: New Member of the "0" Club!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Dogdollar, as many of the other guys I had surgery for my PC, it is now 3 months ago. The months before surgery was stressful and I also had too much to drink during that time. But remember that your diagnosis is not too bad. It can be fixed and when it has been fixed you will be almost as good as new. Many of us have issues with minor incontinence and more or less ED but it can be handled. What helped me is the fact that my type of PC (3+4) is slow and there is time to decide, and to fix it. Today probably the stress and alcohol is hurting you way more than the PC. I believe that the stress will decrease the day you make a decision on treatment plan. Because then you are doing something about it and you are back in control. And treatment choice is very much a 50/50 choice between surgery and radiation and a matter of taste in side-effects. But both will have good odds of fixing you. Try to get educated and read everything in here and then make a decision. Then it will feel better Good Luck

AgeInfo.Phrase: is very much a 50 50 choice between surgery and radiation

Posts.Title: Stomach bloating after surgery....

Posts.Content: Hello Frenchy, Sorry to hear about your diagnosis but welcome here. I think the reason there is not much about proton here is that it is not used very much. I discussed it with my doctors but since I have a steel hip joint it could not be used. However they said that it had no significant advantages over traditional radiation or brachytherapy. But listen to the experts. Most people here chose surgery, but not all, the success rates are equal and basically a matter of personal preference and trust in your surgeon or onchologist. Diets and other life-style-changes are fine before you get the cancer since being healthy decreases your risks of getting it at all, however when the cancer is there diets will not cure it, only surgery or radiation will cure it. I am sorry to say that there are no real easy ways to fix this, all methods have pros and cons, but it is certainly doable and many guys here will witness of that. And life will be good after treatment also, very much so compared to the alternative. Good Luck and keep posting, I am sure others also will give their opinions.

Posts.Title: 2.5 years post surgery; Update

Posts.Content: When I just had gotten the news I had cancer I read a lot and in some place (I think it was here) a guy said that having PC was "like a long very slow dance with death...." I thought hm, that would make a great tattoo so two weeks ago I had my first tattoo which is just a guy having a slow dance with a female death. There is no point to this post but one and that is that I am technically cured I guess, I have <0.1 in PSA but I still feel like I have cancer. Many have advised me to "just define yourself as cured" but I struggle with that. I prefer to be realistic and never stop being vigilant on the PSA and I am quite happy with that. The dance with death feels ok and hopefully reeeeeeeeeally long and slow. Cheers comrades

Posts.Title: Friday afternoon off-topic

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Dogdollar Remember the old thought exercise, Schrodinger's Cat, where a cat is place in a box with a radioactive substance, a Geiger counter, a hammer, and a vial of poison? The box was rigged so that the radioactive material, which had a 50/50 chance of emitting radiation in the course of one hour, if the substance DID emit radiation it would pe picked up by the geiger counter, which in turn was rigged to drop the hammer onto the glass vile of poison and kill the cat......but, simply by observing the sealed box, tha exact state of the cat could not be determined, and so for all practical purposes, the cat was both alive and dead at the same time, until someone actually opened the box and observed the system. I find that having PCa is a lot like being Schrodinger's Cat.People, with all of their good intentions, congratulate you on being cured, because, in the here and now, you have had the cancer removed, and your PSA is non- detectable....but what the Pca patient himself deals with is the spectre of a re-occurrence, and the plain reality that no one is really a cancer survivor until the day they die of something else. Where you wind up finding the most comfort is in knowing that whatever the ultimate outcome, you have improved your chance for a good prognosis by leaps and bounds in taking the actions you have taken. Best regards, DD That is a really good comparison. It is exactly like that.

Well there is always wine And on life expectancy it is true, the Swedes are a tough kind, I trust my genes to fix this.

Posts.Title: Finally on Day+1

Posts.Content: Hello Frenchy, Sorry to hear about your diagnosis but welcome here. I think the reason there is not much about proton here is that it is not used very much. I discussed it with my doctors but since I have a steel hip joint it could not be used. However they said that it had no significant advantages over traditional radiation or brachytherapy. But listen to the experts. Most people here chose surgery, but not all, the success rates are equal and basically a matter of personal preference and trust in your surgeon or onchologist. Diets and other life-style-changes are fine before you get the cancer since being healthy decreases your risks of getting it at all, however when the cancer is there diets will not cure it, only surgery or radiation will cure it. I am sorry to say that there are no real easy ways to fix this, all methods have pros and cons, but it is certainly doable and many guys here will witness of that. And life will be good after treatment also, very much so compared to the alternative. Good Luck and keep posting, I am sure others also will give their opinions.

Posts.Title: Follow up with Surgeon

Posts.Content: When I just had gotten the news I had cancer I read a lot and in some place (I think it was here) a guy said that having PC was "like a long very slow dance with death...." I thought hm, that would make a great tattoo so two weeks ago I had my first tattoo which is just a guy having a slow dance with a female death. There is no point to this post but one and that is that I am technically cured I guess, I have <0.1 in PSA but I still feel like I have cancer. Many have advised me to "just define yourself as cured" but I struggle with that. I prefer to be realistic and never stop being vigilant on the PSA and I am quite happy with that. The dance with death feels ok and hopefully reeeeeeeeeally long and slow. Cheers comrades

Posts.Content: My personal theory is that there is no physical shrinkage but with your nerves bruised or cut the blood flow to your penis is close to none, so your poor penis is in the stage of "after ice-bath" all the time. It has not really shrunk, it is terrified. I eat cialis 5mg every day which does not give any erections but it has increased the blood flow to the normal level which means that my penis looks like it used to do. Good enough for me

Posts.Title: Shrinkage following DaVinci

Posts.Content: Hi Bricks, I took Cialis 5mg fro the first months after surgery, this did not create any erections, but it is supposed to avoid the dreaded shrinkage. I tried Muse, which works but hurts and is a bother (you should use a condom because if Muse leaks into the lady parts she will hurt also and be very unhappy...) Now after 8 months I have stopped the Cialis and I work fine if I take a viagra. It is still getting better and I truly believe that I will get back to needing nothing at some point but I am fine with the Viagra. You need some patient in the ED game.. Good Luck

Posts.Title: An Essay on Penis Shortening.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Sometimes I almost feel guilty when relating the relatively "easy" post-op experience I enjoyed. And yet, it's important to mention it, from time to time, because it IS one of the possible experiences of recovery and it might be helpful to those going in with lots of fear. Chuck, it is a double-edged sword. Some guys have a smooth journey and some absolutely not. But I think all stories needs to be told for the guys starting their PC trip. With the risk that some of them are disappointed but some surprised at how smoothly it went. We were two guys having surgery the same morning in my hospital. The other guy went home the day after wearing JEANS, that is actually true. Very little pain for him. I stayed for 6 days...

Posts.Title: Post Op Rant

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by jorola No you read right on the numbers and no he has not had surgery. His dr told him that surgery would most likely cause the cancer to become super aggressive and did not recommend it. He also said by no surgery he would have 10 to 12 good years. He is currently 67. Hi Jorola, I am no expert but that sounds a little strange, His PSA is high but in no way extreme, and it is moving around a little but it does not seem to rise quickly. He is only 67 there is no reason as I can see whatsoever to not treat it. Has he had any scans showing the cancer has spread? If not I would check that and also get a second opinion from an expert. But I donÂ´t know your fathers doctor or the results from the biopsy which may indicate something else. I strongly recommend you get those results. I also know how stubborn old men can get when it comes to their health and at some point it gets to you even if you are the strong and silent type of guy so maybe it is just wearing him down. My father although older is just like that. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Dad's prostate cancer - thoughts?

Posts.Content: Not much to add to all the good advice but one simplification that helped me: 1. PSA only gives a warning 2. free PSA gives a little bit more 3. A biopsy even more but only exactly from where it is taken 4. If prostate cancer spreads - there is no cure, there is a lot of other stuff that can be done and time will get new treatments, but here and now no cure For me that said that I would maybe do AS if I had G6 in few cores and I would still do regular biopsies and PSA tests, but with G7...fix it now. Statistics is statistics, the problem is that no single case of PC are alike, and neither are side-effects from treatments. There was a point where I could have flipped a coin on radiation vs surgery and gone with it, and it probably would have been fine. I went for surgery and I will not look back, side-effects have been fine for me. I am sorry if I sound blunt but unfortunately there is no way of predicting a specific case, you may become incontinent, you may become impotent, the cancer may spread, and maybe not. Very many get cured and live with the side-effects in a good way. Good Luck and stay positive (even after listening to me..)

As the others have said to track your PSA is important but no matter what you do have time to make an informed decision. Posts.Title: First Post-op PSA

Posts.Content: Brian, I guess I was lucky on this issue, after 7 weeks I am almost continent, small squirts on surprised laughter etc. 1 thin shield/day. I have noticed during my period that things improved in steps and some of them happened quickly. For example leaking getting out of the car stopped over a day, then nothing happens during a period. Also it is very individual, I would recommend doing the kegels, for me it felt as if the muscles "woke up" when I did kegels. So what I am trying to say is that even if it is a marathon improvements now and then happen quickly.

Posts.Title: Scheduling/choosing Treatment

Posts.Content: Not much to add to all the good advice but one simplification that helped me: 1. PSA only gives a warning 2. free PSA gives a little bit more 3. A biopsy even more but only exactly from where it is taken 4. If prostate cancer spreads - there is no cure, there is a lot of other stuff that can be done and time will get new treatments, but here and now no cure For me that said that I would maybe do AS if I had G6 in few cores and I would still do regular biopsies and PSA tests, but with G7...fix it now. Statistics is statistics, the problem is that no single case of PC are alike, and neither are side-effects from treatments. There was a point where I could have flipped a coin on radiation vs surgery and gone with it, and it probably would have been fine. I went for surgery and I will not look back, side-effects have been fine for me. I am sorry if I sound blunt but unfortunately there is no way of predicting a specific case, you may become incontinent, you may become impotent, the cancer may spread, and maybe not. Very many get cured and live with the side-effects in a good way. Good Luck and stay positive (even after listening to me..)

Posts.Title: How do you process all the information?

Posts.Content: Hi Craig, and welcome here. Weather you have a 3+3 or a 3+4 remember that the chances of being cured are very good, and as I understand your report the tumor is also not very big so you have time to get educated. If you never have had surgery there are some things you should know: It hurts after the surgery, and painkillers can handle it so that you can take it. Important thing to remember is that the pain is normal and does not mean something is wrong. Try to eat and walk as much as you can, that helps and getting your digestive system on track is important. The catheter and other practical stuff is nothing to worry about at all, if you read the stickies and stories here you will be well prepared. And the healing curve is steep, two weeks after surgery you will be pretty well back to normal. Feel free to post any questions here and Good Luck

Posts.Title: Another newbie...decided on surgery

Posts.Content: Hi, I had my surgery in January and was pretty much continent 6 weeks later. Now 6 months later I really have no incontinence issues apart from the fact that when I have to go, I have to go now. That is no issues but one, and it is stupid. Living in Sweden I am right now on a 5 week vacation and having spent a lot of time with my wife I have noticed that every single time I hug her and maybe squeezes her ass in a loving way I squirt. Every time...And it is embarrassing since she notices how I kind of freeze mid-hug and goes to the bathroom. It is really messy when it happens wearing swim-shorts. Due to ED we have not really tried to have sex yet but now I am getting a little concerned that I will just start squirting uncontrolled if we try it. Well since dignity is way behind me I am not that concerned but just wanted to ask if any of you guys have also experienced this little problem?

Posts.Title: Good Luck Highlander

Posts.Content: I am so sorry but I think that you should listen to the oncologist who should now best what the odds are for radiation. Cured is also a question about definition, at the end it is all about odds...Unfortunately it sound as if your husband still needs to hit it hard again and that he will have side-effects that will be hard on him, but the positive thing is that side-effects as incontinence is better handled the younger you are and he seems to have recovered quickly after surgery so there is hope that he can handle also the radiation well. Others have more experience on radiation but my small advice would be to not listen too much on the statistics, we are all very different and very many here have beaten the odds.

Posts.Title: Post-op question

Posts.Content: Hi all, just took the energy drink which will be my last meal before surgery tomorrow and also took the Klexane-shot in my bellyfat. Luckily I had a hip-replacement a year ago and know how to take the shots. Also I am quite calm since the pain from the hip-replacement probably was way worse than what tomorrow might throw at me. Packed my bag, loose pants, several underwear, iPad loaded with movies and books. Stored man-pads for several weeks, made guest bed with rubberized sheets, bought prune-juice and all kinds of fruits and soups. Filled car with gas and checked weather for tomorrow. There probably are astronauts less prepared for space..... Thank you all for your advice and support in this forum. See you on the other side.

Posts.Title: 12 Hours to go....

Posts.Content: IÂ´m Baack! Had a bumpy road and came home today after 6 days in hospital. Surgery went well, no issues with bladder spasm and in the wake-up I felt fine, sigh leakage from the catheter but a young nurse rapidly washed my boys and I was fine. The surgen spared the nerves on one side and partly on the other side but given the size of the tumor he was happy. There was a small leak in the suture so I had to have a drain in place. The most remarkable memory was the handwritten note taped on the daVinci robot saying "Do not unplug, batteries will drain!" (True!) However the drain added one day in hospital to check that leakage stopped. But then came the hard part, I bloated severely, my digestive system shut down. Day three I looked pregnant and started vomiting and where given morphine against the pain in the bladder area where gas probably pressed the bruised areas. The drain was removed which did not hurt but felt straight unnatural. Day four a minor fart and more vomiting. Nurses actually at one point said "we can see that you are in such pain that you should take more morphine". No BM but clear fluid. I did walk around as much as possible, I did take laxatives. Day five monumental fart happened after actual doing toe-touches in bathroom and pain stopped however the doctors said that evenso the swelling was so big that if it did not go down I would need an x-ray of my abdomen. However on day five things continued to get out of me and in the evening yesterday I could eat and basically feel ok. Then I also realized that the pain from the surgery as such was very minor. And day six I was released. I recognize the stomach issues from my hip replacement and I believe that this is a side effect of surgery that now and then can happen but with a prostate removal you worry more because the pain is in the same area. So here I sit and watch TV with a bag at my leg and a pregnant stomach but feeling ok.

Posts.Title: Still a member!

Posts.Content: IÂ´m Baack! Had a bumpy road and came home today after 6 days in hospital. Surgery went well, no issues with bladder spasm and in the wake-up I felt fine, sigh leakage from the catheter but a young nurse rapidly washed my boys and I was fine. The surgen spared the nerves on one side and partly on the other side but given the size of the tumor he was happy. There was a small leak in the suture so I had to have a drain in place. The most remarkable memory was the handwritten note taped on the daVinci robot saying "Do not unplug, batteries will drain!" (True!) However the drain added one day in hospital to check that leakage stopped. But then came the hard part, I bloated severely, my digestive system shut down. Day three I looked pregnant and started vomiting and where given morphine against the pain in the bladder area where gas probably pressed the bruised areas. The drain was removed which did not hurt but felt straight unnatural. Day four a minor fart and more vomiting. Nurses actually at one point said "we can see that you are in such pain that you should take more morphine". No BM but clear fluid. I did walk around as much as possible, I did take laxatives. Day five monumental fart happened after actual doing toe-touches in bathroom and pain stopped however the doctors said that evenso the swelling was so big that if it did not go down I would need an x-ray of my abdomen. However on day five things continued to get out of me and in the evening yesterday I could eat and basically feel ok. Then I also realized that the pain from the surgery as such was very minor. And day six I was released. I recognize the stomach issues from my hip replacement and I believe that this is a side effect of surgery that now and then can happen but with a prostate removal you worry more because the pain is in the same area. So here I sit and watch TV with a bag at my leg and a pregnant stomach but feeling ok.

Posts.Title: A few more days until surgery

Posts.Content: Hi Gary, I was diagnosed with G7 in october and was in shock of course. The advice you are given here are excellent and given by guys who are experienced so you are in the right place. The two things that stuck in me which helped a lot was: 1. You are not in a hurry, you have the time to make an informed decision, but with G7 you need to make a decision 2. Talk to an urologist AND an oncologist and if you do not have confidence in them find another. You need input from both sides. Good luck

Posts.Title: I really did not want to be in this club.

Posts.Content: Hi all, just took the energy drink which will be my last meal before surgery tomorrow and also took the Klexane-shot in my bellyfat. Luckily I had a hip-replacement a year ago and know how to take the shots. Also I am quite calm since the pain from the hip-replacement probably was way worse than what tomorrow might throw at me. Packed my bag, loose pants, several underwear, iPad loaded with movies and books. Stored man-pads for several weeks, made guest bed with rubberized sheets, bought prune-juice and all kinds of fruits and soups. Filled car with gas and checked weather for tomorrow. There probably are astronauts less prepared for space..... Thank you all for your advice and support in this forum. See you on the other side.

Posts.Title: An Essay on Penis Shortening.

Posts.Content: Hi, and welcome here, you are in the right place to get information. There are several guys here with similar diagnosis as you, me being one of them. When I made my choice I leaned towards radiation but later changed my mind to surgery mainly because you get an answer weather you are cured quicker and because there is the opportunity to get radiation at a later stage. But that was my reasoning and there are others who reasoned differently and are happy. In either way (as others already have stated) you should try to find an experienced doctor who you also trust. I also think you should remember that with your diagnosis (3+4 confined) you have time to get informed but it does need treatment so when you have decided you probably should not wait. But your doctors can make that judgement better of course. Good Luck

Posts.Title: undecided

Posts.Content: Hello I pulled my catheter 2 weeks ago. This is what I observed: Nights were dry almost from day one which is good. On burning sensation I had that too, I think it is from irritation from the catheter. Also I had no real sensation of needing to pee, but when it came a couple of days later it was very urgent, basically when it came there was an interval of one minute to get to the bathroom. Pain in the perineum is normal for some time after I think. I was told to do Kegels quite aggressively, three times/day from day one. I know this does not work for everybody but it worked for me. Also on all kinds of muscle tensioning I had to really concentrate not to leak, as sneezing, farting, spitting, raising from chair etc. But if I concentrated and tensioned the muscles it got better at say day 4. From what I have read here everybody have more or less problems in the beginning but it does get better. I would do the Kegels if I were you. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Finished SRT

Posts.Content: I had 5 holes done during my RALP, two small to the left, one bigger through the bellybutton one small further to the right and one big (6 cm) furthest right where the prostate was removed from. All where stapled except one small where the drain came out, that one was left to heal on its own. This is the only one with significant scar tissue, all others are visible but very smooth and without bumps or anything like that. It looks like a saturday night knife fight. I also have a 10 inch scar from a hip-replacement which is way uglier. I think it looks rather cool and not embarrassing at all. Like the guy in Jaws...

Posts.Title: Checking In at 3yr anniversary

Posts.Content: Hello Dom555, It may sound strange but it would be more worrying with PSA 33 and no symptoms whatsoever. A rectal exam normally does not hurt much apart from hurting your dignity. Without being trained in any way I would not worry until after an infection has been ruled out. And then not until a second PSA is high. There is not much good with prostate cancer but one thing is that you very seldom are in a huge hurry, it grows slowly and there is time to get educated and make a decision. Good Luck and try not to worry, plenty of experience to be found in here also for advice.

Posts.Title: 3 year update

Posts.Content: Hi, in the beginning it is all about getting blood back into the penis, not really having sex. Without cialis there will be no erections whatsoever and that may lead to problems later and the dreaded shrinkage of the penis.....Normally a guy gets erections in his sleep which guarantees blood flow, after surgery this does not work automatically so cialis is needed. So the first goal should be to get something happening, not necessarily sex. My surgeon told me it was important to "stretch things out a bit" Later on some extra "help" may be needed to get back to 100% for example Viagra or Muse, but the important first thing is really to get blood flow back, sex will come back gradually. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Stomach bloating after surgery....

Posts.Content: Wayne, please listen to Chuck he is giving you good advice. And even if your total diagnosis is not the worst in the world you will sooner or later need treatment. It might not be a big hurry but at 62 a 3+4 cancer will certainly have the time needed to kill you. I am sorry to be blunt, I really am. I would strongly suggest to use the time you have to decide on a treatment and enjoy your days without side-effects, but unfortunately there are very few miracles and very few cancers go away. I am a strong believer in a healthy life-style and the good sides of religion, but I also believe that a healthy life-style might decrease the odds of getting cancer but NOT cure it if it occurs. I think this is often mixed for same. I think you should listen to yourself " I have PCa, 4/12 cores positive, 10% PTI (small volume), Gleason score for 3, 3+3 and the forth 3+4" These are the facts. Get another opinion from one of the institutions recommended here, and go from there. Good Luck and keep posting

AgeInfo.Phrase: a big hurry but at 62 a 3 4 cancer will

Posts.Title: "inactive Surveillance"

Posts.Content: Hi Mik, you have a very similar case as I had. If the path says PT2.....which means the thing did not escape AND your PSA is undetectable you are basically fine for now. You just have to track PSA. DonÂ´t worry about RT until you get the path report. And remember that the PSA needs some time to get out of your system so the first one may be detectable but not necessarily bad. Ask your Uro. This is a waiting game, try to relax and get well and wait for the PSA and path report to see what will come next. Good Luck

Posts.Title: RALP done 2 weeks ago - Next steps

Posts.Content: Hello Frenchy, Sorry to hear about your diagnosis but welcome here. I think the reason there is not much about proton here is that it is not used very much. I discussed it with my doctors but since I have a steel hip joint it could not be used. However they said that it had no significant advantages over traditional radiation or brachytherapy. But listen to the experts. Most people here chose surgery, but not all, the success rates are equal and basically a matter of personal preference and trust in your surgeon or onchologist. Diets and other life-style-changes are fine before you get the cancer since being healthy decreases your risks of getting it at all, however when the cancer is there diets will not cure it, only surgery or radiation will cure it. I am sorry to say that there are no real easy ways to fix this, all methods have pros and cons, but it is certainly doable and many guys here will witness of that. And life will be good after treatment also, very much so compared to the alternative. Good Luck and keep posting, I am sure others also will give their opinions.

Posts.Title: Stomach bloating after surgery....

Posts.Content: Hello Jphil, I think that your husbands biopsy result is a quite common one, there are several guys here with very similar results, mainly 3+3 but some 3+4. I had 6 of 10 3+3 and 2 of 10 3+4. I donÂ´t see a reason to get a second opinion, the 3+4 indicates that treatment is needed and assume that the second opinion gives a 3+3 only result you would never get peace of mind on which opinion is correct. And if higher, well treatment is then also needed. A 3+4 with moderate PSA and nothing felt on the DRE and no symptoms is as far as I see it curable and you now "just" have to decide what treatment you and your husband prefers. I also think that you have time to study before you decide. But an experienced urologist and/or onchologist of course have more knowledge than me. Also this forum have tonnes of info and experiences that helps a lot when deciding. Good Luck and take care

Posts.Title: recooping after surgery

Posts.Content: Hi, in the beginning it is all about getting blood back into the penis, not really having sex. Without cialis there will be no erections whatsoever and that may lead to problems later and the dreaded shrinkage of the penis.....Normally a guy gets erections in his sleep which guarantees blood flow, after surgery this does not work automatically so cialis is needed. So the first goal should be to get something happening, not necessarily sex. My surgeon told me it was important to "stretch things out a bit" Later on some extra "help" may be needed to get back to 100% for example Viagra or Muse, but the important first thing is really to get blood flow back, sex will come back gradually. Good Luck

Posts.Title: R-rated questions about 'rehab'

Posts.Content: Hi Dogdollar, as many of the other guys I had surgery for my PC, it is now 3 months ago. The months before surgery was stressful and I also had too much to drink during that time. But remember that your diagnosis is not too bad. It can be fixed and when it has been fixed you will be almost as good as new. Many of us have issues with minor incontinence and more or less ED but it can be handled. What helped me is the fact that my type of PC (3+4) is slow and there is time to decide, and to fix it. Today probably the stress and alcohol is hurting you way more than the PC. I believe that the stress will decrease the day you make a decision on treatment plan. Because then you are doing something about it and you are back in control. And treatment choice is very much a 50/50 choice between surgery and radiation and a matter of taste in side-effects. But both will have good odds of fixing you. Try to get educated and read everything in here and then make a decision. Then it will feel better Good Luck

AgeInfo.Phrase: is very much a 50 50 choice between surgery and radiation

Posts.Title: Checking in After Robotic Surgery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Dogdollar Remember the old thought exercise, Schrodinger's Cat, where a cat is place in a box with a radioactive substance, a Geiger counter, a hammer, and a vial of poison? The box was rigged so that the radioactive material, which had a 50/50 chance of emitting radiation in the course of one hour, if the substance DID emit radiation it would pe picked up by the geiger counter, which in turn was rigged to drop the hammer onto the glass vile of poison and kill the cat......but, simply by observing the sealed box, tha exact state of the cat could not be determined, and so for all practical purposes, the cat was both alive and dead at the same time, until someone actually opened the box and observed the system. I find that having PCa is a lot like being Schrodinger's Cat.People, with all of their good intentions, congratulate you on being cured, because, in the here and now, you have had the cancer removed, and your PSA is non- detectable....but what the Pca patient himself deals with is the spectre of a re-occurrence, and the plain reality that no one is really a cancer survivor until the day they die of something else. Where you wind up finding the most comfort is in knowing that whatever the ultimate outcome, you have improved your chance for a good prognosis by leaps and bounds in taking the actions you have taken. Best regards, DD That is a really good comparison. It is exactly like that.

Posts.Title: I never get used to it...(PSA-test-angst)

Posts.Content: Hello Frenchy, Sorry to hear about your diagnosis but welcome here. I think the reason there is not much about proton here is that it is not used very much. I discussed it with my doctors but since I have a steel hip joint it could not be used. However they said that it had no significant advantages over traditional radiation or brachytherapy. But listen to the experts. Most people here chose surgery, but not all, the success rates are equal and basically a matter of personal preference and trust in your surgeon or onchologist. Diets and other life-style-changes are fine before you get the cancer since being healthy decreases your risks of getting it at all, however when the cancer is there diets will not cure it, only surgery or radiation will cure it. I am sorry to say that there are no real easy ways to fix this, all methods have pros and cons, but it is certainly doable and many guys here will witness of that. And life will be good after treatment also, very much so compared to the alternative. Good Luck and keep posting, I am sure others also will give their opinions.

Posts.Title: How cancer effects me!

Posts.Content: Hello Davis, I was in a similar situation 7 months ago and there are a few things that might help you, first of all the biopsy is not as bad as it sounds, just abandon all dignity concerns and do it. It does not hurt and it is the only way to get an answer on what is going on. The free PSA suggests cancer but remember that with your low PSA it is probably very early found and/or low aggressive type, and you have time enough to get educated and make a decision. Many of the guys here have done surgery and it very often turns out successfully. The odds are high that you will be fine so read the guys stories here, read the stickies and once again remember that whatever is happening in there you have time to decide what to do and get back in charge of it. Good Luck
