Posts.Title: I guess it's my turn

Posts.Content: Hi all, I took my 3.5 year PSA-test this morning and even if I have stopped worrying in advance of the test (as I used to) when I sit there with that needle in my arm all the old cancer fear pops up. My last two PSA:s were exactly 0.05 which in Sweden is considered measurable (not <0.05) so the test today is special since it will show if I have a rising trend or not. My urologist recommends to wait until 0.2 for further treatment but I am not sure I like to wait that far. So this afternoon I get the results. No point with this thread, just venting.

Posts.Title: I never get used to it...(PSA-test-angst)

Posts.Content: Hello Jonno, I had a very similar trip as you when it comes to constipation and beeing basically totally clogged up. They kept me in hospital 6 days for that reason. As for you day 5 was really a low point. I tried to eat but vomited immediately. Day 6 things started to happen and 7 and ahead the stomach started to work. Beeing clogged up sounds like a minor issue to most people but when it happens and specially in combination with abdomen surgery it is no joke. It hurts like hell and you feel really miserable. And as you say painkillers make it worse. My father had the same problems after a heart by-pass surgery and he also confirmed that the surgery as such would have been quite fine if it wasnÂ´t for the stomach problems. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Five years in the zero club

Posts.Content: Hello Fairland, we have very similar biopsy results, a 3+4 and medium sized. It can be fixed but donÂ´t wait too long to do something. I had surgery in January 2015 and I am today basically back to normal. A year passes quickly. You are young and should handle surgery well if you choose that. I strongly advice you to talk to a surgeon and an oncologist to get a grip of side-effects and make an informed decision. DonÂ´t worry too much, this can be fixed. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Zero Club status still intact

Posts.Content: Yeah, I know, and it is still very low. I did not change to uPSA, the tests are standardized in Sweden and what used to be <0.1 has been changed to <0.05 as standard for undetectable. So I guess according to the old standard I am still OK. The problem is in my head not my body, staying calm and sane is a challenge. Well there is always wine And on life expectancy it is true, the Swedes are a tough kind, I trust my genes to fix this.

Posts.Title: Friday afternoon off-topic

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Dogdollar Remember the old thought exercise, Schrodinger's Cat, where a cat is place in a box with a radioactive substance, a Geiger counter, a hammer, and a vial of poison? The box was rigged so that the radioactive material, which had a 50/50 chance of emitting radiation in the course of one hour, if the substance DID emit radiation it would pe picked up by the geiger counter, which in turn was rigged to drop the hammer onto the glass vile of poison and kill the cat......but, simply by observing the sealed box, tha exact state of the cat could not be determined, and so for all practical purposes, the cat was both alive and dead at the same time, until someone actually opened the box and observed the system. I find that having PCa is a lot like being Schrodinger's Cat.People, with all of their good intentions, congratulate you on being cured, because, in the here and now, you have had the cancer removed, and your PSA is non- detectable....but what the Pca patient himself deals with is the spectre of a re-occurrence, and the plain reality that no one is really a cancer survivor until the day they die of something else. Where you wind up finding the most comfort is in knowing that whatever the ultimate outcome, you have improved your chance for a good prognosis by leaps and bounds in taking the actions you have taken. Best regards, DD That is a really good comparison. It is exactly like that.

Posts.Title: Friday afternoon off-topic

Posts.Content: Hello Mary, Your husbands data are very similar to mine, 6 of 8 cores and some 3+4, I had 8 of 10 with 2 3+4. Now I have to agree strongly with Chuck. Many cores positive indicates a large tumour and 3+4 indicates somewhat aggressive type of cancer. The problem is that the biopsy cannot be detailed enough to say how close to the edge the tumor is (how close to escape to the outside). This is unfortunately a kind of digital situation, if you get it all out and it has not escaped the odds are very much in your favor, if not the odds go down quite fast. Not saying that it cannot be fixed if it escaped, just saying that it is easier before. My tumor was in aftersight bigger than expected and very close to the edge (positive margins) in two places. But now it is out an that feels good. Personally i sometimes can hear the bullet passing 1 mm over my head... I would not wait, I would treat it and sooner is better. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Plumbing issues

Posts.Content: Hello Logic, On the Viagra before surgery I donÂ´t know, however I cannot imagine it could hurt and you may have a good time. I did Kegels before surgery and maybe it did not matter but at least I learned how to do them and it felt good to do something. I think that very many of us are slightly depressed or emotional after surgery and certainly many are more or less incontinent but the important part is to remember that this is normal and that it will get better, really it will get better. Try to have a good time before surgery, eat and drink, spend time with friends and rest. That is my non-expert advice. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Diagnosed in Atlanta

Posts.Content: For me it felt very strange but did not hurt, the nurse told me to take a deep breath and I closed my eyes and did it and of course when I exhaled he pulled it out. Took 5 seconds. I never gushed out pee, I was laying down when he pulled it and nothing happened. I put a diaper in my briefs lying down and when I stood up he told me "now you will leak" and sure enough. But nothing like a waterfall, just a leak. The best thing ever was to be able to shower without the miserable thing tugging my penis. I bet you will find it very undramatic. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Next PSA on the way

Posts.Content: Hello Jonno, I had a very similar trip as you when it comes to constipation and beeing basically totally clogged up. They kept me in hospital 6 days for that reason. As for you day 5 was really a low point. I tried to eat but vomited immediately. Day 6 things started to happen and 7 and ahead the stomach started to work. Beeing clogged up sounds like a minor issue to most people but when it happens and specially in combination with abdomen surgery it is no joke. It hurts like hell and you feel really miserable. And as you say painkillers make it worse. My father had the same problems after a heart by-pass surgery and he also confirmed that the surgery as such would have been quite fine if it wasnÂ´t for the stomach problems. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Oh Crap, I lost my <....

Posts.Content: Hello Davis, I was in a similar situation 7 months ago and there are a few things that might help you, first of all the biopsy is not as bad as it sounds, just abandon all dignity concerns and do it. It does not hurt and it is the only way to get an answer on what is going on. The free PSA suggests cancer but remember that with your low PSA it is probably very early found and/or low aggressive type, and you have time enough to get educated and make a decision. Many of the guys here have done surgery and it very often turns out successfully. The odds are high that you will be fine so read the guys stories here, read the stickies and once again remember that whatever is happening in there you have time to decide what to do and get back in charge of it. Good Luck

Posts.Title: I Guess I'm Paranoid!

Posts.Content: Hello pjr, sorry about the worry you have to face. I had similar PSA and fPSA as your husband and as I had it explained the PSA could be slightly increased for several reasons but a fPSA <20% indicates cancer, however not necessarily aggressive cancer. I think you should see it as a reason to go for a biopsy, if the fPSA would have been >20% maybe a retest of the PSA would have been in order. Having said that a PSA of 6.5 and fPSA of 14.4% is not very high and if it is cancer there are good odds that it is curable. This can however only be confirmed by a biopsy so I suggest you do it. There probably is no hurry though. But if you are worried by all means get it done soon to get the confirmation what you are dealing with. Also tell him not to worry about the biopsy, a dentist normally will hurt you worse. (Dignity on the other hand of course have to be abandoned.......)

Posts.Title: After surgery,now what

Posts.Content: For me it felt very strange but did not hurt, the nurse told me to take a deep breath and I closed my eyes and did it and of course when I exhaled he pulled it out. Took 5 seconds. I never gushed out pee, I was laying down when he pulled it and nothing happened. I put a diaper in my briefs lying down and when I stood up he told me "now you will leak" and sure enough. But nothing like a waterfall, just a leak. The best thing ever was to be able to shower without the miserable thing tugging my penis. I bet you will find it very undramatic. Good Luck

Posts.Content: Hello, I had a similar situation as You, my surgeon said that it was risky to do nerve sparing but that he would take the decision when he saw what it looked like in there. And at the end of the day he did spare all nerves on one side and almost all on the other. Today I am glad that he did it that way, I am sure I would have been completely devastated if he would have said that nerve sparing was possible and during surgery changed his mind in the other direction.... It is very much about the trust you have in the surgeon and his/hers experience.

Posts.Title: Oh Crap, I lost my <....

Posts.Content: Hi Wendy, not much to add to what already has been said but since I had similar biopsy results as your husband I may be an example what can happen. I donÂ´t believe you want to do AS with a G7 and with a PSA of 20. The relatively high PSA may indicate that there is more going on and that the biopsy did not catch everything so I would not risk AS. Having said that the PSA varies between individuals and it may be that he has a low/medium grade tumor and that surgery will fix him without any big issues. The main reason I went for surgery is really the definitive biopsy results you get afterwards and then you will know much better what was going on. But when it comes to treatment success rates surgery and radiation is basically at par. As already have been advised a chat with both a urologist and an oncologist is strongly recommended. I had a talk with both at the same time and my wife was there also and that was really helpful. Good Luck and donÂ´t hesitate to ask questions.

Posts.Content: Hm, never had that issue. I used the leg bags all the time and only connected as an extension the big bag during nights. I had one issue with the leg bag and that was that all the three ones I got leaked when full and specifically if I placed it at knee height and bent my leg. This seemed to apply some pressure and it leaked. Since the pee was warm I didnÂ´t notice until I had more or less filled my slipper. Pee all down the leg. The other time I forgot to open the drain valve to the big bag during night causing the leg-bag to be very full and leak down the bed. Friday will come soon enough and you will be happy to switch one pee-problem to another but I never missed the catheter, at least it did not hurt a bit to pull it out. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Foley follies

Posts.Content: Hi Hilander, as the others say statistics does not help you at this stage, there is just too many unknown. What you do know is that your PSA is 6.1 which is higher than normal but can come from other issues than cancer. But if it is cancer 6.1 is not very high and indicates that it can be successfully treated. But one step at the time, do the biopsy and read all info here and the recommended book. DonÂ´t worry too much, the biopsy is not bad and after that you will know what to do. Good Luck

Posts.Title: 2.5 Days to go

Posts.Content: Hello pjr, sorry about the worry you have to face. I had similar PSA and fPSA as your husband and as I had it explained the PSA could be slightly increased for several reasons but a fPSA <20% indicates cancer, however not necessarily aggressive cancer. I think you should see it as a reason to go for a biopsy, if the fPSA would have been >20% maybe a retest of the PSA would have been in order. Having said that a PSA of 6.5 and fPSA of 14.4% is not very high and if it is cancer there are good odds that it is curable. This can however only be confirmed by a biopsy so I suggest you do it. There probably is no hurry though. But if you are worried by all means get it done soon to get the confirmation what you are dealing with. Also tell him not to worry about the biopsy, a dentist normally will hurt you worse. (Dignity on the other hand of course have to be abandoned.......)

Posts.Title: Concerned Partner

Posts.Content: Hi Wendy, not much to add to what already has been said but since I had similar biopsy results as your husband I may be an example what can happen. I donÂ´t believe you want to do AS with a G7 and with a PSA of 20. The relatively high PSA may indicate that there is more going on and that the biopsy did not catch everything so I would not risk AS. Having said that the PSA varies between individuals and it may be that he has a low/medium grade tumor and that surgery will fix him without any big issues. The main reason I went for surgery is really the definitive biopsy results you get afterwards and then you will know much better what was going on. But when it comes to treatment success rates surgery and radiation is basically at par. As already have been advised a chat with both a urologist and an oncologist is strongly recommended. I had a talk with both at the same time and my wife was there also and that was really helpful. Good Luck and donÂ´t hesitate to ask questions.

Posts.Title: Cranberry pills

Posts.Content: Hi Mike, As Chuck said progress is different for all, but I can understand your frustration. As I get it there are three steps of progress: Dry at nights Dry while walking Dry while doing unusual movements like standing up, sneezing... It sounds like you are somewhere between 1 and 2. I did Kegels a little different, I did 10 6 seconds hold, 10 2 seconds hold and 2 60 seconds hoooooold. This three times a day. I also have heard of guys only doing Kegels once a day, I think it is possible to overdo it. Maybe you should try some variants? But I am no expert so ask your urologist. I had a smoother incontinence journey than you but still it felt hopeless at times and what helped was weighing the pads to keep track of daily leakage and by doing that I could see progress even if it did not feel like that. Also progress comes in steps, so donÂ´t get too worried, one day it just gets a step better. Good Luck

Posts.Content: Hello EasyBreezy, and welcome here. You will find answers to your questions here for sure. First of all: DonÂ´t Panic! If you can get your fathers PSA-value and biopsy results it is easier to give better advice so try to get that information. With most prostate cancers you are not in a big hurry, you can take your time to get educated and your father can make an informed treatment choice. The book ddayglo recommends is also very good. Good Luck

I hope that might do it. Good Luck Brother

Posts.Title: 18 months PSA Undetectable ð

Posts.Content: Hi Gene, and welcome here. I donÂ´t have much to add that the others have not said but a small comment on ED, it can take months or even a few years but it very often comes back. The nerves are both bruised and partly damaged but they are also very tough, so donÂ´t give up it gets better. On treatment choice i just agree with everybody, I think you are doing everything right. Hit it good and hard... Good Luck

Posts.Title: New to the "Club"

Posts.Content: Hi Mike, As Chuck said progress is different for all, but I can understand your frustration. As I get it there are three steps of progress: Dry at nights Dry while walking Dry while doing unusual movements like standing up, sneezing... It sounds like you are somewhere between 1 and 2. I did Kegels a little different, I did 10 6 seconds hold, 10 2 seconds hold and 2 60 seconds hoooooold. This three times a day. I also have heard of guys only doing Kegels once a day, I think it is possible to overdo it. Maybe you should try some variants? But I am no expert so ask your urologist. I had a smoother incontinence journey than you but still it felt hopeless at times and what helped was weighing the pads to keep track of daily leakage and by doing that I could see progress even if it did not feel like that. Also progress comes in steps, so donÂ´t get too worried, one day it just gets a step better. Good Luck

Posts.Title: HMS SRT Log 1 down 33 to go

Posts.Content: Thank you all, words fail me trying to express how grateful I am for your support. I am on Cialis now and I also are using Muse which somewhat works but hurts, I will opt for the shots next time. I am up for the 6 month PSA test and follow-up very soon so I will talk to my urologist then. I realize it is a short time since surgery and I realize I could be way worse off, it is just that some days it is hard (pun unintended). And in two weeks I will have a 5 week vacation, and I will not let ED ruin those weeks. Have a nice midsummer all of you, even if you donÂ´t celebrate it as in Sweden.

Posts.Title: How do You cope?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by SubDenis Yes, that’s the elephant in the room, will it come back? What I know at this stage is that is a question that has no answer and there is nothing I can do to address it, so I am going to stay the course, live life to its fullest and do the next right thing. Hi Denis, This is important and I have the same experience, even if the treatment may offer a cure how and when do you know that you are "cured"? When I got PC me and my wife decided that when all was done we would get at tattoo with the date I was cured as a reminder. Well that never happened since I cannot even today say I am cured. What you say sums it up perfectly "stay the course and live life to the fullest" Take care

Posts.Title: Reflection on my cancer journey as I enter the treatment phase.

Posts.Content: Hello EasyBreezy, and welcome here. You will find answers to your questions here for sure. First of all: DonÂ´t Panic! If you can get your fathers PSA-value and biopsy results it is easier to give better advice so try to get that information. With most prostate cancers you are not in a big hurry, you can take your time to get educated and your father can make an informed treatment choice. The book ddayglo recommends is also very good. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Incontinence Progress

Posts.Content: The last part is hardest, I was like you after 5 weeks, occasional dribbles when yawning or spitting. I would say today after 7 months I have one really small dribble/week. The last thing I learned to master was squeezing my wifeÂ´s butt... DonÂ´t stop doing Kegels, but donÂ´t overdo it. I do them once a day and if I stop the leaking increases. I think it is for life to do Kegels. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Alternative Medicine?

Posts.Content: It is midsummers eve in Sweden, the night when 25% of all babies are conceived here. And according to all results I am well, PSA is down and surgery went fine. I am continent enough, but totally impotent. My wife is fine with it all and I love her, but this sexless life sucks the joy out of me. And I see guys all around die of this hellish disease and I just have a hard time to feel happy. So please advice, how do you all cope with it? Or am I just a whining child? I drink way too much and am tired all the time. Sorry to be whining but I just have nowhere else to ventilate this.

Posts.Title: How do You cope?

Posts.Content: As I see it this is primarily an issue if you consider AS, I never took a second opinion since it would not have changed my decision to go for surgery (two cores with 3+4, six with 3+3). If I would have a second opinion downgrading I would have gone for surgery anyway (because who am I to judge which one was right) and if upgraded even more for surgery. This was one of the main reasons I went for surgery since the pathology report after surgery will give me some peace of mind on what I am dealing with. (Still hoping for nothing worse than the 3+4). But that is me, I realize we all think differently.

Posts.Title: Question about the value of a 2nd opinion on the biopsy slides...

Posts.Content: Hello Ron, and welcome Since you are only 51 there is a risk that AS will only work for a limited time for you and then you need some other treatment as surgery or radiation. Both will to some extent change you physically and in your age ED is hard to live with. So FranÂ´s advice is a good one, have as much sex as possible..now! I had worse cancer and had to have surgery and I still dream about my glorious autumn 2014 when sex was good. But donÂ´t worry, surgery is (as many here will agree with) not as bad as it sounds, and also radiation will be another option that others also can give advice on.

Posts.Title: DX Last Week.....

Posts.Content: Well as they say "Life sucks and then you die (but first you have to pay taxes....)" But your cancer is for sure of a kind that can be fixed and the cardiac issue is probably better to find out about sooner than later. What I am trying to say here is that it is good to find these issues in time so that they can be fixed compared to find out when it is all too late... Good Luck

Posts.Title: 3 months after da Vinci...first post op PSA

Posts.Content: Hi Rebern, Your Uro has a point. fPSA is a second indicator of cancer. I am really sorry to say this. My Uro (in Sweden) has a limit which says that fPSA<20% indicates cancer and if you have fPSA lower than this a biopsy is recommended. PSA can fluctuate and biking may affect it, but combined with a low fPSA I would recommend you to take the biopsy and get the issue either off your agenda or on and if so to start planning your treatment options. I am sure others here will also give more advice. I did my surgery in January and I am back on the bike now. It feels good. Good Luck

Posts.Title: How do You cope?

Posts.Content: It is midsummers eve in Sweden, the night when 25% of all babies are conceived here. And according to all results I am well, PSA is down and surgery went fine. I am continent enough, but totally impotent. My wife is fine with it all and I love her, but this sexless life sucks the joy out of me. And I see guys all around die of this hellish disease and I just have a hard time to feel happy. So please advice, how do you all cope with it? Or am I just a whining child? I drink way too much and am tired all the time. Sorry to be whining but I just have nowhere else to ventilate this.

Posts.Title: How do You cope?

Posts.Content: Hello Ron, and welcome Since you are only 51 there is a risk that AS will only work for a limited time for you and then you need some other treatment as surgery or radiation. Both will to some extent change you physically and in your age ED is hard to live with. So FranÂ´s advice is a good one, have as much sex as possible..now! I had worse cancer and had to have surgery and I still dream about my glorious autumn 2014 when sex was good. But donÂ´t worry, surgery is (as many here will agree with) not as bad as it sounds, and also radiation will be another option that others also can give advice on.

Posts.Title: DX Last Week.....

Posts.Content: Hello Jlynn, The others have basically covered everything, just adding some reflections. Your husbands data are very similar to mine (and many others) I had G3+4 and PSA around 6. My tumour was bigger though. I did surgery in january. I went for surgery for two reasons, you get a very final analysis of the tumor and the cancer is out of you. I was very concerned about the side-effects, primarily incontinence, but that has worked out well, after roughly 5 weeks it was ok. As Shu says the plumbing is different and it will never be as before but my wife told me "You are as continent as any woman who have had babies" ED is an issue but still to early to judge. The majority in this forum have chosen surgery but I believe that is more due to gut feeling "get it out of me!" than radiation being less effective. Most guys here who chose radiation are very happy. The odds of success are as I understand it basically the same. Whatever you decide it is a good thing to get in shape before the treatment, do the Kegel exercises and enjoy the physical parts of a marriage as it may be affected for a period. You have plenty of time to decide so get educated and read the other guys stories here and read the stickies at the top. Good luck

Posts.Content: The last part is hardest, I was like you after 5 weeks, occasional dribbles when yawning or spitting. I would say today after 7 months I have one really small dribble/week. I think it is for life to do Kegels. Good Luck

Posts.Title: How long after the drips started???

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by CPO2CWO It seems that last year when I joined the Club, there were a lot of reports that people had incontinence problems for extended lengths of time. But now, it appears that a lot of people report of being dry by two or three months post surgery. I have noticed this also, could it be that the DaVinci methods are getting better and better? It is a rather new method. Witnesses from 10 years ago seems to have more incontinence issues. Or the guys who have no problems just stop talking about it and move on...

Read the stickies here and get in touch with your urologist on Monday. Did he take a free PSA test also? that complements the PSA with info on if the PSA is due to cancer or something else. DonÂ´t freak out, no reason with this data (easy to say and hard to do, I know)

Posts.Title: Psa 0.04 after 4 and a half y after RP

Posts.Content: Hi Rebern, Your Uro has a point. fPSA is a second indicator of cancer. I am really sorry to say this. My Uro (in Sweden) has a limit which says that fPSA<20% indicates cancer and if you have fPSA lower than this a biopsy is recommended. PSA can fluctuate and biking may affect it, but combined with a low fPSA I would recommend you to take the biopsy and get the issue either off your agenda or on and if so to start planning your treatment options. I am sure others here will also give more advice. I did my surgery in January and I am back on the bike now. It feels good. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Got 8 week post surgery follow-up and first PSA score today.....

Posts.Content: Hello Dooley and welcome here, the club where no-one wants to be a member. With your 4+3 you do need treatment and if your choices are limited the important thing is as you say your surgeons experience. If he has performed say more than 500 and preferably several per month you should be fine. I also agree with ASAdvocate that you should prepare yourself for the side effects that will happen, you will have incontinence for a period and your ability to get an erection will be poor. But for most guys (not all) this is a question of time. Read the stories here and you will get a good picture of what life after surgery will be like. There is no point in sugarcoating this. Having said that I had surgery exactly a year ago and I donÂ´t regret it. It feels really good to have the tumor out. Good Luck to You

Posts.Title: Psa 0.04 after 4 and a half y after RP

Posts.Content: Hi SC, I had three PSA:s taken the first year after surgery and now I take it every 6 months. So next up is August. The last time which was the 12 month we also agreed that I will not see my surgeon for every coming PSA but have a phone follow-up with a junior doctor. I am fine with this as long as the PSA is undetectable. It seems like a 6 month interval is commonly recommended after 12 months. I donÂ´t think you need to take it monthly. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Got 8 week post surgery follow-up and first PSA score today.....

Posts.Content: Hello Dan, Yeah itÂ´s a real party this game. But you should give the incontinence some more time and do the Kegel exercises, they work. On ED I would also give it more time. I am now 9 months away from surgery and it works with Viagra now but not as before...Still improving though. Constipation is also a real party, I had it and to be frank the sixth day I was ready to cry. Not joking. But you will get better, believe me. And your PSA is really good. If the ED gets too frustrating try Muse or the trimix injections, they work. Remember that even though there are guys who donÂ´t leak at all and have erections like stallions immediately after surgery most guys donÂ´t, but time heals and it gets better. DonÂ´t give up and Good Luck

Posts.Title: Update on SRT + ADT

Posts.Content: Hello Habhammer, The others are giving good advice and I really have nothing to add but one thing: with a G3+3 in only one core you are for sure not in a hurry to decide. Read the book, read the stickies here and read the other guys stories. With surgery you get all the side-effects from day one and then things improve with time, with radiation I think it is the other way around. It is really a matter of personal taste I think, the success-rates are about the same. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Kind of freaking out a little!

Posts.Content: Hello Borddeleau54, your urologist may be rude, but a PSA of 8.2 and a fPSA of 16% unfortunately indicates cancer and a biopsy is the next logical step to check if you have cancer or not. I have never heard of anybody having issues after a biopsy (I may be wrong here) but I have heard several having issues with prostate cancer. You may have it or not, but a biopsy is the only way of knowing. It is your call but even if your urologist may be rude, the fact is that a biopsy may be needed. Good luck

Posts.Content: Hello Pratoman, Sorry to hear about your issues. As you know I have been eating Cialis for about as long as you and as I understand it there are a spectrum of side-effects however all quite uncommon and not so severe. So you should be fine now that you have attention on the issues. I get dissy almost every morning for about ten minutes, normally while leaving for work. I am quite convinced that this is due to Cialis also, but my blood-pressure is fine so I just live with it. On ED however Cialis seems to be a small help for me...

Posts.Title: Merry Christmas Brothers! (Off topic)

Posts.Content: Hi Paul, As the others said, you have plenty of time to handle this. Having said that you are also quite young and you need to keep monitoring the cancer since it may later need treatment. You do not want the cancer to spread. Having said that there is a theory that G6 cancer donÂ´t spread at all. It is also correct that life changes after treatment, but not always in a disastrous way (I am quite fine...) so donÂ´t be too scared. I had surgery and a good surgeon and incontinence is gone and erections are ok (but yes, only ok, not more) Lastly, as you move along in your journey this place is a goldmine of advice and friendship. I donÂ´t know how I would have coped without it. (Thanks guys) Good Luck

Posts.Title: New guy

Posts.Content: Hello all, from a nervous Swede.. I am rather new to this and would highly appreciate some advice. I had a high PSA/low free PSA quota identified by coincidence as a test done prior to a hip-replacement I needed. A kidney value was high and so a PSA was taken, later the kidney value was back to normal but PSA not. I had a biopsy taken on oct. 31 and had the results a couple of weeks later. 10 shots were taken, Gl 3+3 in 6 and Gl 3+4 in 2 of them. Urologist (who is very experienced) said that this is curable with both surgery as well as radiotherapy but, with the rather extensive tumour, if he were to operate he cannot guarantee that nerve-sparing will be possible. He will though give it a try. I have after this spoken to another experienced urologist as well as an oncologist and they say basically the same thing, it is curable. I decided on surgery, since I have already one hip replaced radiation is doable however Proton beam cannot be done if you have a steel hip.... I picked surgery basically with the reason that I will get a definitive answer on how bad it is. I do not like the fact that I have cancer pretty much in all of the gland so I want it out. But of course I am concerned on ED with few or no nerves spared. Today i received my date for surgery which will be jan 7th. Any comments or advice is highly appreciated

You may have it or not, but a biopsy is the only way of knowing. It is your call but even if your urologist may be rude, the fact is that a biopsy may be needed. Good luck

Posts.Content: Hello Habhammer, The others are giving good advice and I really have nothing to add but one thing: with a G3+3 in only one core you are for sure not in a hurry to decide. Read the book, read the stickies here and read the other guys stories. With surgery you get all the side-effects from day one and then things improve with time, with radiation I think it is the other way around. It is really a matter of personal taste I think, the success-rates are about the same. Good Luck

Posts.Title: Advice or comments on my treatment choice

Posts.Content: Hello all, from a nervous Swede.. I am rather new to this and would highly appreciate some advice. I had a high PSA/low free PSA quota identified by coincidence as a test done prior to a hip-replacement I needed. A kidney value was high and so a PSA was taken, later the kidney value was back to normal but PSA not. I had a biopsy taken on oct. 31 and had the results a couple of weeks later. 10 shots were taken, Gl 3+3 in 6 and Gl 3+4 in 2 of them. Urologist (who is very experienced) said that this is curable with both surgery as well as radiotherapy but, with the rather extensive tumour, if he were to operate he cannot guarantee that nerve-sparing will be possible. He will though give it a try. I have after this spoken to another experienced urologist as well as an oncologist and they say basically the same thing, it is curable. I decided on surgery, since I have already one hip replaced radiation is doable however Proton beam cannot be done if you have a steel hip.... I picked surgery basically with the reason that I will get a definitive answer on how bad it is. I do not like the fact that I have cancer pretty much in all of the gland so I want it out. But of course I am concerned on ED with few or no nerves spared. Today i received my date for surgery which will be jan 7th. Any comments or advice is highly appreciated
Posts.Title: Advice or comments on my treatment choice

Posts.Content: Hello Pratoman, Sorry to hear about your issues. As you know I have been eating Cialis for about as long as you and as I understand it there are a spectrum of side-effects however all quite uncommon and not so severe. So you should be fine now that you have attention on the issues. I get dissy almost every morning for about ten minutes, normally while leaving for work. I am quite convinced that this is due to Cialis also, but my blood-pressure is fine so I just live with it. On ED however Cialis seems to be a small help for me...

He also said by no surgery he would have 10 to 12 good years....Originally Posted by jorola No you read right on the numbers and no he has not had surgery. His dr told him that surgery would most likely cause the cancer to become super aggressive and did not recommend it....Hello Sawdustmaker, I had a similar diagnosis as you have and went for surgery. I would recommend to bring someone with you to the visit to the surgeon, even if you seems to be really well prepared it is a stressful meeting and hit is easy to forget to ask the questions you planned and even harder to remember the answers....
